description:
The service was excellent!

I am from out of town and visited a friend who took me here. We weren't able to get to Napa on my trip so she took me to this wine bar that had some napa (as well as global) selections. The guys behind the bar select all the wines are were *extremely* knowledgeable. Fully knew a lot about the wine. I told them what I typically like and they suggested several wines that they also let me taste before committing to. I actually think they let me try just about everything on the menu. Fantastic service and overall experience.

I see some reviews that talk about the service. I had no problem. They were extremely kind, attentive, and willing to work with what I like and recommend new things. I just suggestion being nice in general and I think they are nice.

I got a cheese board that was decent. They also have a wine club membership that locals can pick up there. Being from out of state they also said I could have it shipped.
author: Kate O.

description:
More than a decade ago, I'd come here many times to enjoy wine by the glass and it was always a great way to start an evening out before heading to dinner.

Last night, I stopped in to treat myself to a nice bottle of white with some minerality. 

I'm not great at picking wines on my own so I appreciated the expert advice; it was spot on (Enkidu 2016 Grenache Blanc Sonoma/Lodi).

The owner asked if I wanted to try a small glass before buying- which was thoughtful especially since I was buying an inexpensive bottle of wine ($25)- but I couldn't linger since my little boy was waiting for me.

Chill ambiance, excellent wines you can buy retail -for your evening in!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Do NOT go to this establishment if you care about the rights of people with disabilities. I arrived with a colleague who, after spending time in the defense sector, had a service dog for panic attacks. When the management asked about the dog's service, my friend clarified that the dog would alert her about the onset of anxiety attacks. After serving us, the manager then grabbed the wine out of our hands and informed us that they only permit service dogs for people with physical disabilities- not mental or psychiatric ones. This was not only humiliating to my friends and me but also a clear violation of the law. I have never seen such atrocious treatment of human beings before. Please do not support this wine bar and their despicable behavior. 
The response below also clearly demonstrates an unfamiliarity with the law. There is a distinction between an ESA and a psychiatric service dog: https://www.servicedogcertifications.org/the-difference-between-a-psychiatric-service-dog-and-an-emotional-support-animal/
author: DF C.

description: I had the best night last night. After a very terrible happy hour, I walked into California Wine Merchant to collect my thoughts and sit down for a moment. A calming vinyl was playing, and the bar was full of calm and happy couples that seemed relaxed amongst anything. Chelsea behind the bar instantly poured me a glass of phenomenal Sauvignon Blanc, which I proceeded to buy a bottle of almost immediately after tasting. She was light-hearted, attentive, and knowledgeable of the wine behind the bar. I instantly felt at home, but even more so once I met her parents (and the owners- Greg and Deb). The entire family was upbeat, jovial, and made me feel entirely at home, even though I'm 2,000 miles away from my own family! If you like delicious wine, a calming and gorgeous atmosphere, please stop by California Wine Merchant. I know I'll be back shortly.
author: Taylor L.

description:
Good place with a long bar and few tables around to sit. I liked the feel inside. Very crowded though (July 3rd evening). 

Loved their Paso Robles wine and found prices to be decent. Just didn't fall in love with the abrupt service. 

Conveniently close to Delarosa if you're waiting for a table, which is main reason why we stopped here for a glass of wine before our dinner reservation.
author: Heliana M.

description: A very relaxing spot to enjoy a glass of wine and watch the world walk by.  Every changing glass pours ensure you'll have an opportunity to sample a bunch of different styles.  Staff is knowledgeable about what could end up in your glass.  If you don't know what you want, don't be afraid to ask for a tasting, they'll work really hard to make sure you're going to enjoy what you're drinking.  Best seat in the house is by the front windows as they're often open for you to enjoy the breeze on a warm day.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This place is pretty small, so it can be pretty hard to get a seat, especially on a weekend. 

Food: The cheese plate is just a single cheese with some fresh bread, pistachios, and olives. It's good, but nothing amazing. It would've been great if the platter had more variety.

Wine: I got the rose, which was decent. It was a drier more acidic rose, which I appreciated over the usual sweet stuff. 


I might go back to try some of their other wines, but I'd probably hit up one of the other wine bars in the city over this one, given the choice.
author: Kavita P.

description:
Disrespectful service. 

We simply refuted one thing on the bill and immediately was threatened with camera surveillance and accusations of being cheap and to "f*ck ourselves," we simply looked for an answer as to why something was charged double than the listed price and was met with defensive and aggressive behavior. 
As we began to adjust the tip on the receipt, which they refused to reprint, she snatched it away and began shouting for us to get out, not to be cheap, with plenty of profanity in between. 

Spare yourself the bad vibes of this spot and enjoy the services of a respectful establishment elsewhere.
author: Sachit S.

description: A fan. A good local hideout. Bartenders are good, wines are good, crowd is local, they filter in and out throughout the night, and most know each other. Old couples, new nervous dates, friends, neighbors, does not have a trendy pick up joint vibe to it like some on Chestnut. Would recommend, just don't bring annoying loud friends with you, just the surreptitious whimsical kinds
author: Juls C.

description: Super fun spot! They have a great selection of wines and a fun staff. Sunday nights are so fun. They play '80's music and the place gets packed.
author: Danielle S.

description: My wife and I have been coming here since we moved to the Marina 3 years ago, and it's our favorite spot on Chestnut. Not only is it a great vibe to have a glass of wine, but we are members of the wine club, which has introduced us to tons of new winemakers. Club is 5 reds and 1 white each quarter, all from different wineries. It also includes about 40 free Monday night wine tastings a year including all the winemakers of the bottles in the club shipments. Greg, the owner, is often around and takes good care of us. Regardless of how long we live in the Marina, we'll always make it back to CWM.
author: Nick G.

description: Stopped in on a Sunday. We loved our bartender Hailey! She was so friendly and knowledgeable. We will definitely come back.
author: JSL V.

description: Used to like this place. But new manager is a hater. Walked in with some friends, and immediately he was giving us attitude. He tried to start a fight with one of us, so we left. Just wanted some wine. When did this become the Vallejo wine merchant? I predict it closes in six months.
author: Pierce B.

description: Love this wine bar in the marina. It's tucked away amongst the craziness and an open air wine bar with awesome music. They also have a wine membership that would be great if I lived in that part of town. The cheese board and olives were simple but delicious and they had all sorts of wines to choose from. Definitely a good pop in spot if you want something different that your typical marina sports bar!
author: Carol Ann V.

description: Just wanted a glass of wine on a rainy night at our local wine bar, but found the attitude of the bartenders to be worse than the rain.  This isn't the first time we've experienced this but tend to hope for the best.  Our fault.  Sorry, Deborah (the owner), but I think we have to find a new, more friendly spot.  We overheard them talking about us after ordering a cheese plate as if we were putting them out for spending money. Congrats fellas, you got what you wanted- we won't be back.
author: Yvette B.

description: The owner was extremely cold and very rude because we brought our registered seizure warning dog with papers. He had no compassion and it was very strange to be treated so rude after running a big tab. Usually owners want business and are kind to customers. The only good part was the bartender, who was an awesome guy.
author: Brittany P.

description: One of the best wine bars in SF! The service is amazing and the owner makes sure that you feel like family the second you walk in. They are very knowledgable about all of the different wines and encourage you to try a wide variety of wines until till you find the best! Their wine club could not be more fun to start the week each Monday with 6 different tastings!
author: Kathleen D.

description: I've been to the Wine Merchant on occasion over the past five years and have always found their wines to be a little overpriced compared to other options in the city. I think the space could use some serious updating, but there is something a bit charming about the place after you look past the dated decor. I'm giving this place five stars based solely on my experience with the two bartenders who were working (Marie and Joel, I think) the night I stopped in. They were fun, friendly, informative and played great music. I didn't mind looking past the high prices in this case given their level of service.
author: Lindsay T.

description: What else can I say, the California Wine Merchant is hands down the best wine bar in San Francisco and maybe all of California for that matter. That statement might raise a few eyebrows, but they have been doing this since 1974 (before the Paris Tasting of 1976 that put California wine on the International stage). It seems like a new trendy wine bar opens up every week in the Bay Area that is pouring overpriced and generally bad wine. Most of it is from California and there is no shortage of mass produced bad wine in this state and people usually don't know the difference (if this is you just go to the Marina Safeway). The owner here (Greg) and his wife (Deborah) go out of their way to find the best small production wines from across the world and bring them to your doorstep. Weekly free tastings by the wine makers for club members make this a no brainer for people living in SF and don't want to make the 3 - 4 hour round trip to wine country and deal with the hassle of booking private tastings. It's an amazing value and experience if you enjoy good wine and live in SF. Just avoid Friday & Saturday, since those days bring out the absolute worst crowd in the Marina - particularly at this place and it's impossible to deliver a great customer experience under the circumstances. If you love good wine and a variety, consolidate your wine club memberships and add this one to your portfolio!
author: Russ Z.

description: The owner is shit steak Greg, he hates dogs.  I shook his hand and had to wash it.  Grimy guy, dyes his hair and it doesn't even look real.  On a less shallow level, turns out prosecco tastes bad when the owner is a shitsteak
author: Austin t.

description:
This wine bar is an absolute hidden gem, right in the heart of everything happening on Chestnut street in the marina. It is perfect for any occasion and always a wonderful atmosphere. There is a truly incredible and unique selection of wines to try and purchase in store. They also have some incredible connections with elite wineries getting you great deals, incredible wines and all the inside scoop ;)

The service though is what makes this place stand out. Even when it is packed to the brim on their Monday evening tasting nights, the owner Greg and staff are extremely attentive and make you feel like you are the most important person in the room. This should be your first and ONLY stop for wine tasting, wine purchases and a good time!
author: Molly H.

description: Found the BEST wine bar in the Marina! The owner, who has been in the wine business for over 40 years, makes you feel like a VIP. Even during a busy night, he was our groups personal sommelier, and the nicest man in town. They also have the BEST wine club deal around, which gets you HUGE discounts and FREE wine tastings every Monday. Awesome atmosphere, with a great music playlist and vibe. If you haven't been... GOOO!
author: Zak F.

description: Friday night I had a very sad experience on Chestnut Street. Sad because, California Wine Merchant is much of what it advertises itself to be.    A cozy bar that features high caliber wines from small exceptional wineries.  A perfect place for two girlfriends to meet after work about 6:00PM, and it was. Originally. Then at about 7:00 one bartender decided to turn it into the Fillmore.   We asked our server, being at the end of the bar if he would return the volume to a level that allowed you to have a conversation with your wine.  He did.  Then this arrogant little man who also sadly resides behind the bar turned it right back up. Right in front of us.  Repeating the request, our server, who was lovely, again turned down the volume.  The response of his coworker was to walk right over and turn it up.  This happened 4 times. It was only 7:00 PM. We should have left, but my girlfriend was only halfway through her cheese plate, and we had full glasses of wine.  Our original server stopped by to see if we were enjoying our evening. I told her the story, and that I suppose we're not the demographic they are looking for. As long as they  employ wanna be cool  jerks that have no comprehension of service.  I mean really, when was the last time you said to yourself, "I want to open a beautiful bottle of wine and blast my music until my ears bleed."  If so California Wine Merchant is perfect for you!  I'll never go back.
author: C W.

description:
A retail wine shop/wine bar on Chestnut st. specializing in various California wine regions. They also carry well curated imports. 

I wanted to try one of the "Last Call" wines and decided on the Count Karolyi Grüner Veltliner, but they ran out. So I had to settle for my second choice, a Rose. (Maybe they should call it the "you're too late list?!")

I feel that the prices are more expensive than normal, but they do have half glass prices too.

The ambience is laid-back, with some uncomfortable wooden chairs at the back of the wine bar next to the makeshift "office" area.  Sit near the window if you like people watching.

I prefer the Cellar Door on Fillmore for a better ambiance and same expensive prices.
author: Janice C.

description: Mediocre wine. The person pouring wine was very snarky and inattentive. Just saw the same employee get into a verbal altercation with a customer tonight. I won't be coming back. Ever.
author: Diana G.

description:
I come here once a year when I make it to San Francisco.  They have a good selection of boutique wines, but then again so do many in the area as this wine country. I was also surprised to see a few grocery store wines.  The 2 gentlemen behind the bar could not be more unpleasant and unhappy. They make you feel like they are doing you a favor by pouring wine into a glass. First time I have ever experienced this in a wine bar.  Wow!

ZERO personality and not an environment to relax and drink good wine at. They made us want to spend our money in a place that actually wants customers. Save your money. At least now I will be open to discovering many of the other wine bars in the neighborhood.
author: M I.

description: I have been going to the Wine Merchant more often in the last several months. I prefer Sinday when Marie is working. She is on top of her game, plays great tunes and is easy to speak with. Many times I come in after Warriors games and just want to relax and unwind with a glass of wine, easy conversation and good tunes. Thanks Marie for making it easy!
author: Allan B.

description: California Wine Merchant is great! The owner, Greg, is awesome. Not sure what's better, him or the Wine Club Member deal!! Just kidding, they're both are. The membership allows the member and a guest to do a free wine tasting every Monday night and any additional person after that is only $20. Greg has been in the industry for 40+ years and has created a little gem in the Marina of SF. The music is great, service is great and they know their wines (as you'd hope). If you don't want to check out the club membership, at least go check out the wine bar occasionally.
author: Leah M.

description:
Hate to wine but...
Good grapes go to die here. Tears.
Staff are bad vintage.
author: Nish N.

description:
I arrived in San Francisco a few days early for work and had the chance to make a few stops with an old buddy. California Wine Merchant was one of them.

Small, casual, affordable and lacking pretension, CWM is a great little detour when in the neighborhood - definitely not an upscale grape bar. Our bartender for this particular pitstop was, John. Nice feller... a bit soft spoken but able to casually chat you up without being that stereotypical bartender guy. 

The selection is great and your wallet doesn't have to take a beating unless you want it to. If you're looking for that, they're happy to oblige. Is it a place that you'll want to spend all night in? For me, no. For you? Maybe. I get my fix, sip a little wine, chat up a few of the beautiful locals before moving on down the block. Small doses, friends.

See you next time, CWM!
author: Brad B.

description:
Come here for the best wines in the City and totally awesome staff!

There's also an incredible wine club featuring top wines from off the radar small wineries that knocked my socks off! It's $200/Q for six wines, including free 'meet the winemaker' tasting on most Mondays.
author: Jason E.

description:
I won't pretend to be the vino expert that I'm certainly not but here are my two cents. 

Small wine bar / seller on Chestnut, selected wines only, in the upper price range (glass: $9-$17, bottles +$45). Bar seating and a few tables. Intimate decor, rustic. Will get packed easily!

I'm not too fond of paying that much for a glass of vino but I liked the chatty yet relaxed atmosphere in there. Crowd is mixed - some old folks and the young&beautiful.
author: Sebastian F.

description: The bartenders are super rude. I have 3 friends that were all overcharged tonight and all the bartender did was argue and yell and scream at them. Later she was screaming at them when they were on the sidewalk! Some blonde girl behind the bar seems off her meds. One of my friends mentioned her to someone he knows in the neighborhood and they said that she has the reputation of having a bad attitude. If you go there, all I can say is pay for every drink one at a time. No open tabs!!! She is a little scammer.
author: Lori S.

description:
Stopped by here on my visit to the Bay area. It's a pretty small venue with lots of wood and dark accents. The wine menu provided a variety of tasting options; however, I felt that the prices were a bit steep in comparison to other sellers in the area. 

Still, a nice place for a casual drink.
author: Hye Eun C.

description:
A-OK. This place is in a wonderful little area of San Francisco- perfect for tourists and residents alike. It's got an indoor farmer's market feel. 
The place is pretty small so its not great for large groups. Lots to choose from though and the staff are really nice!
author: Monica C.

description: Worst wine bar in SF. Please let me begin with the actual bartenders are awesome - Super nice and they provide speedy service. However, you are paying way too much for "decent" wine and they measure every pour as if their lives depend on it. No really. Maybe that's the case.  The owner is a total jerk and denied my state certified service dog. That's fine dude. Your bar sucks and you should own a coffee shop. No offense to coffee shops. ‍
author: Lisa K.

description: My husband and I stumbled upon this little shop one Saturday afternoon and left with a wine membership (that was NOT pushed on us at all, just gently presented.) Since then we have been coming back for the wine tastings (usually$20 per head but free for member + 1 guest) on Mondays. Greg is the owner and so very personable, you can often find the ever-so-friendly&helpful Jacob behind the bar. I see a lot of people complaining about their prices but look around people, you think their prices can stay stagnant with the area they are in? The Marina is expensive and that isn't something likely to change. This place is a gem not to be missed!
author: Sonia M.

description:
This place rocks! I've walked past it a million times, and finally decided to step inside- and I'm so glad I did! The prices are all very reasonable ($8 cheese plate? Multiple glasses under $13? yes please) and the service is great. 

The coolest part is that this place is that it's super authentic. The owner opened it in the 1970s (in a different location nearby) and has fueled his sweat and joy into it ever since. For example, all of the racks of wine surrounding the seating area are handmade by the owner himself, with wood he selected from a local lumber yard (how do I know this? He came over and introduced himself and told us!). This place is the real deal- come check it out.
author: Caroline B.

description: Horrible! Woman working at bar was completely rude. We walked in from dinner around 6pm and she was far less than pleased. Do not recommend!
author: Brenda G.

description: Stopped by because we had some time to kill before dinner on Valentines Day.  Sat at the end of the bar.  Girl behind the bar was carrying on a conversation with the couple next to us.  She pushed to menus over to us and continued talking to the other couple (it was obvious that she knew them because they were talking about furniture, not wine).  She never said hello, she never asked us if we wanted to order.  We sat there for a good 15-20 minutes.  She was, I swear, not 5 feet from us.  I could have reached out and touched her.  I kept looking at my boyfriend and we kept looking at her waiting.  She never even looked at us.  We got up and left. And even as we were getting up, putting on our coats, she still didn't even acknowledge us.  Won't be going back.
author: Lynn A.

description: This is a decent casual wine bar. My experiences here haven't been exceptional, but I haven't had bad ones either. It's a nice stop for a glass or two of their wines  on  a day of strolling alongside Cestnut.
author: Sara N.

description: Staff was drunk(!), inattentive, and arrogant. They turned up the music super loud so holding a conversation was impossible. Upon asking to turn down the music a little bit, the waitress just looked at me with an attitude and walked away - she then turned the music up even more. The two waiters definitely had a good time, they were openly drinking, engaging in heated conversations, and completely ignored their customers - who weren't having a good time! I won't return!
author: Yasine K.

description: Very nice staff and the wine selection was nice.  The pours were a bit skimpy and the prices were HUGE!
author: Sheryl M.

description:
California Wine Merchant was a short walk from where we were staying so it was nice to pop in, grab a seat at the bar & have a glass of wine after a long day of touring the city.

I had the Neal 2011 Zinfandel Rutherford Dust Vineyard from Napa Valley-it was delicious!  My husband had a glass of a Petite Syrah, don't remember the name, doesn't matter, mine was better.  A glass was $17.00 so a little pricey but we were on vacation.
author: Joyce V.

description:
Um, wow?! I had no idea this place existed until my GF and I stopped in for a drink. Turned out to be a really great time. It was packed the night that we went but the bartender was kind enough to scope some seats for us. We ended up at the bar (even though my GF ended up with gum on her bottom- who does that?!) 

They offer an assortment of wines by the glass. My friend usually orders a white while i'm a bit Pinot fan. A couple of girls next to use enjoyed a cheese plate, which I am kinda kicking myself for not getting. 

No scene, no douchy bros in flops. Great wine, awesome bartenders and a great place to stumble upon. Highly recommend! I will be back for HH someday!
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Stopped for a wine flight. The staff were friendly and the place was clean and rustic feeling. The 2 flights we got were ok.  The wine wasn't the best but that's not their fault. Nice place to sit and enjoy some wine while at Pier 39!
author: Ashley N.

description:
Too expensive for the kind of wines they serve.
I have been to a lot of different wine bars in the entire northern California. While I love spending on good wines for which this area has a good number of wineries and bars, I hate to see when some places try to rip you off.
author: Tee E.

description:
Meh.

Smaller wine selection for the close proximity to major winemaking region.

This spot is smallish, although nicely decorated, and falls a bit short in the wine department (which is supposed to be what they do). I wish they showcased more local, California wines. 

Expect the clientele  to be an accurate representation of the Marina crowd.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Small place but found a seat. Could order tastes of wine and I liked that. They have a variety of wines, not necessarily ones I'd like but they have a variety nonetheless. 

Opened a tab and someone else said they wanted to pay it but the person working there went ahead and charged my card anyway and didn't let the other person pay. Come on staff person, if someone offers to pay: let them! 

it's not a place I'd think of first if I was looking for wine in the Marina but if I did remember it, I suppose I'd go back.
author: Asa R.

description: One of my neighborhood go-tos for a happy, friendly vibe with great wines. Unfortunately my friends and I had a less than stellar experience last night with two female bartenders that were obnoxiously non-observant, catty and whom we actually overheard gossiping about customers. They seemed drunk and failed to take any women at the bars order's, but paid close attention to the men. Having so much experience in the customer service industry, this was disheartening at best. Probably won't be back! On another note, there is a great wine bar that just popped up on Union and Fillmore called West Coast Wine -- would recommend avoiding California Wine Merchant's rapidly declining and snobbish vibe and heading over to this new and cozy spot where they serve Belle Glos by the glass and seem way more invested in the venture of what creates a great wine bar experience.
author: Ashley C.

description: Great service and knowledgeable staff.  Wine selection is good but horrendously overpriced if drinking in - expect to pay 3-4x over retail.  If you are taking away prices are decent though marked up versus buying in a wine shop.
author: N.I. G.

description: For a wine place, I think the menu is surprisingly underwhelming. The service was ok. Small shop so not good for groups more than 3 people. The server was nice and helpful in selecting the right wine.
author: Jen L.

description: Paid $65+ for a bottle from the menu.  Later found out the same wine to buy take out plus corkage was $20 cheaper.  Could have been an accident but never given the option. Not going back!
author: Sf W.

description:
The wine selection is great. 

I tried: Bieler Pere et Fils 2012 Rose - Coteaux, France. It was nice and fruity and I enjoyed it.

My friend tried: Mauta 2011 Sauv. Blanc - Marlborough New Zealnad. Did not care much for this one at all...


The glasses are a bit overpriced.

The hostesses where horrible! Not friendly at all! One hostess gave us our check before we were done drinking.

One of the hostesses poured herself a Rose, jut to realize she picked  non-chilled bottle.Poured the drink rite out of her glass into the bottle and stored the bottle...i assume to be used for later customers...that is not professional! 

I will not go there again...
author: Mary N.

description: So this is one of my favorite wine bars in the city, very home-y feeling. My friends and I call this place Greg's because the owner, who is the nicest guy ever, his name is Greg. If you come here a few times you will start to feel like a local - the bartenders take time to ask you about your day, start to remember your name, ect. I just love that about this place, makes you feel at home. Anyways - good wine selection, and I like that they have a "last call" page where you can get a glass from some of their limited selection that week. The only downside is that there isn't a charcuterie platter here, BUT they do have a cheese plate with this amazinggg soft gouda that seriously melts in your mouth
author: Kelli L.

description:
I used to like this place, but their prices have really gotten out of control. The ambiance certainly isn't worth $14 per glass and let me say, they are NOT generous with their pours. Sure you can buy a bottle, but you'll pay a $15 corkage fee on top of the $$$$. There are MANY other wine bars within a 2-block radius, that this is one you can certainly skip. 

Advice to the owners, remember what made you where people wanted to be. There's too much competition for you to be as expensive as you have become.
author: C W.

description:
There's an art to wine. And wine, like art, may not have my complete understanding, but I know what I like.

If you like CA grapes and forcibly booty grinding/dropping The People's Elbow on your attractive neighbor patron, then by all means, head to the California Wine Merchant. The pours from less-than-engaging "corkers" will be carefully measured, and you'll most definitely not be subjected to egregious bar chatter. Blank stares, OTOH, are a dime a dozen.

If you like a palpable personality to boost the mood fueling your excuse to juice (or, say, a reasonably priced bottle), look elsewhere. I've been to packies with more of a sociable, inviting feel. Of course, with a ho-hum name like California Wine Merchant, perhaps we should have known better.
author: Damien S.

description: Nice wine selection, great location. Staff that works don't really know their wine and are far more interested in playing on their phones than serving clients. I asked about a particular wine and the guy went about the region, not the wine, which led me to believe he didn't know much about the wine. Also, we bought a bottle and he poured me a complete glass (without allowing me to taste). When I asked what if the wine was corked, his response was " The wine is not corked". As a certified sommelier, I take wine service seriously - clearly, the folks at CWM don't. Definitely visit but keep low expectations.
author: Rumesha A.

description:
I'm not even close to what you would call a wine connoisseur. I just drink the stuff, so in terms of selection and what not I can't really say how this place compares to other wine bars, but it's okay. 

It's small, there's not a lot of seating (besides the bar itself there's only a few tables & chairs here and there), and quit frankly I'm not really into the really dark lighting they have going on. The bartenders seemed friendly enough and at the end of day (or I guess I should say, the beginning of the night) my glass of Sauvignon Blanc was just fine. 

For me, this definitely isn't a place to hang out at all night, but it's fine to just pop in for a glass of wine to start your evening.
author: George A.

description:
Nothing out of the ordinary, in a neighborhood I usually wouldn't visit for social outings. Had drinks with friends when I was in town, they suggested it due to location and it served its purpose. It did close at like, 11, which was a bit early, even for a Monday night. 

Relatively small selection for a wine bar, we were basically ignored by the staff, but were very obviously different from the rest of their clientele.
author: Liz G.

description: Waiting for boyfriend to get out of work and all the Marina women start talking to me about why I am drinking alone. The Chenin Blanc was incredible and the bartender was nice. Not into the Marina vibe though.
author: Amanda M.

description: I just bought a $27.99 bottle of Cabernet here (from their retail shop) that tastes like a $15.99 bottle. Well, I guess that's because it is. I looked online and found it 20 places for $15-$16. Ugggh.
author: Adam L.

description:
California Wine Merchant is an intimate little wine bar! I've never been to a wine bar but so this was my first experience at one of these places. The ambiance was perfect and would definitely recommend this place if your goin on a date or catching up with a friend.  

Loved the selection of wines and the Riesling was sooooo gooood! The cheese plate paired well with my wine and I couldn't get enough of the pistachios and cheese. The bartender John was awesome and provided great suggestions...the service couldn't have been any better!

Just an FYI: be careful when going down the stairs after using the bathroom because the flight of stairs is pretty steep...sooooo if you've had a few glasses of wine you might wanted to hold on to that handrail (especially if you're wearing heels). 

Overall, I really enjoyed this place and would recommended it to any wine lover if you're in the marina!
author: Nicole Dawn A.

description:
A great casual wine bar I used to go to when I lived in SF. Gets busy during happy hour and Friday/Saturday nights, but fun. Always a good list of wines by the glass. Since it's a wine shop too, you can buy a bottle and open it there for a small corkage fee. But it's totally worth it--don't make the mistake I've made there often, which is having a glass with a friend, then another and maybe another, and then asking to be charged the cheaper bottle price instead. Ain't going to happen. 

Looking for food? They've got a cheese plate, and only a cheese plate. Cheese, bread, olives and pistachios. What more do you need?

Guys: on Sundays during football season, when all the local dudes were at sports bars, I would go in to find myself the lone male surrounded by a dozen young women. Not a bad way to spend a Sunday afternoon...
author: Tom M.

description: Numerous wine selections, however the greeting is mind blowing The Manager  personally introduced himself to me which made me feel special. The wine selections are numerous. Believe it or not the sound system is incredible. Experiance the journey into your taste buds cheers and vino!!!
author: Leonardo M.

description:
- service was just OK
- prices were a bit high (but probably near par for the course in the area)
- selection was a bit underwhelming

All in all, this wasn't a bad little spot.  The girlfriend and I had actually intended to head to Nectar a block or two down the street, but they weren't open yet (it was before 5).  We took a stroll through the area and came across California Wine Merchant.

I thought the idea of using the wine crate lids along the top of the wall was awesome!

CAWM couldn't be anything other than 3 stars for me...nothing really stood out in favor of or against this wine bar.  There are probably several better stops in the immediate area (again, I'd recommend Nectar Wine Lounge).
author: Joe D.

description:
Great spot! 

This wine bar is awesome - very cool and chill bartenders. The crowd is mixed - young and old, hip and more relaxed, etc.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
How clever of this wine bar and market to use pieces of the wooden wine boxes with each winery's logo on them as decoration plastering the walls of this small, laid back place. Almost competes with my fav interior wall accent of exposed brick, so they definitely get credit for that!

Overall, this place does have some bottles you can buy for decent prices, but as far as buying by the glass, the average glass will be about $9, and there is no happy hour prices here either, so if you do come here, be prepared to spend a bit. Good thing they at least pour very full glasses here, which I always appreciate. They also have a pretty awesome selection with a couple tasty Malbecs and a few Spanish tempranillos which are my favorite wines by far. Definitely a quiet spot, and a sort of random group of people that filtered in and out.

Also they get a bonus for actually being open before 4pm which lots of bars in this area I guess aren't, but then again they are also a wine store.
author: Sarah G.

description: Greg and his staff are the friendliness wine merchants in the world. Very knowledgeable and helpful. A lot of great wines not available elsewhere to taste. Enjoyable and comfortable wine bar. Reasonable prices. Join the wine club and get 6 great wine selections every quarter. Also come to the Monday night wine tastings and meet the vintners. What's not to like??
author: Bob M.

description:
I've been here countless times when I lived in the Marina and usually go with a girlfriend of mine that knows one of the main sommeliers.  And in the past I would have given this place at least 4 if not 5 stars... perhaps it has finally hit me this past Saturday, in that I now agree with the stereotypical label that the "Marina" gets.

Five years ago, I used to love hanging out anywhere on Chestnut... not just because it was walking distance, but people seemed cooler... Now there's belligerant, obnoxiously loud WT douche bags with their skanky girlfriends that can't have a normal conversation with their friends without having to scream across the bar when their friends are sitting right in front of them.  I was thankful when my date politely asked the drunk next to us to tone it down since he was screaming in our ears.  Of course the guy got bitch-slapped by the ignorant chic visiting from East Bay by saying that we are in a bar... that it's normal to scream in a bar.  Really?! And apparently the staff here condones that behavior, which I find disappointing to say the least.  I would expect this more from Monaghan's.  Classless.
author: Myra M.

description:
My girlfriends and I were here for a girls weekend in mid December.  We found this place by coincidence and were very pleasantly surprised!!
The wine, cheeses, music and service were superb.  We were helped with our wine selections by a very sweet young lady named Tara who was not only very knowledgable, but equally as fun.  All in all, I recommend this place highly, and I know I'll be visiting again!
author: Ada C.

description:
A tiny little wine bar tucked away on a side street in the Marina. Cute place to get together with a friend or two, but not really ideal for large groups. The place is super tiny and doesn't have a whole lot of seating.

I stopped in here on a Tuesday night around 9pm and the bar was already full. Luckily we spotted two chairs and a barrel-like table toward the back of the place. It was a nice little setup. I'd actually recommend chilling at the barrel table if on a date -- it was more romantic than being at the bar.

It's also really cool that the walls are stocked with wine bottles, so it's a very cozy vibe.

More of the story: Get there early or forget it.
author: Mansi A.

description:
We stopped by after dinner at Isa. The wine bar was nicely packed, but we got 3 seats at the bar. 

They change the menu daily but i was very happy to see Orin Swift's the Prisoner on the list. I tried the Petit Syrah though, and my friends tried the Syrah and Merlot. we got 3 glasses and they were all very good. 

Service was really good. The servers were really personable and made conversation easily with all the customers.
author: Debby L.

description: Nice feature is that you can order wine bottles even late at night, after it's mostly being used as a bar.
author: Tom P.

description: Great selection of wines. Very friendly bartenders and the cheese plate was excellent! Great little spot... especially great to stumble upon it as a tourist... love finding places that don't feel "touristy" (even if it really is.... I have no idea).
author: Ali K.

description:
Cannot say enough GREAT things about this place.  If you are looking for an unpretentious place that doesn't at all meet the Lululemon, North Face feel of the Marina this is it.  Struck up conversations with other wine bar patrons and it was a relaxed, comfortable environment with an edge (they play great music).  Service is amazing - the folks that work there have on a few occasions directed this freshman level knowledge about wine and steered me in perfect direction.  They ask questions about what you are looking for/what's the occasion/price point and have delivered every time.  An added bonus is they don't stick a nose up or think I am a tool because I don't know wine - they speak at my level and make fantastic recommendations.

Anyone who says "you can't get a seat" as a negative needs to seriously reassess - If having your ass planted in a chair is more important than a good glass of wine then don't go out - run up to Bevmo, look at the 93 point + (which is all BS) and you can sit on your couch!
author: Brad P.

description: Greg the owner is amazing.  This place is for folks that actually appreciate wine.  He talked to us, we were just off the street into his place, for hours.  The guys knows everything.  Amazing wines, amazing company.  Gotta check it out!!
author: Michael L.

description:
The only reason this isn't getting 5 stars is because:
1. ALWAYS SO CROWDED. even just trying to stand there can be difficult because the place is small'
2. SOMETIMES bad customer serice. Younger sommilers or bartenders tend to be unfriendly and SOMETIMES flat out rude! My friend and I were there for a long time and she had to use the rest room. As she is walking up, the bartender yelled at her and said he was closing in 2 minutes and she couln't use the bathroom...very strange

Anyway-besides that, i really enjoy coming here and grabbing a glass of wine or champagne and a snack. They have a yummy cheese plat with olives, cheeses, pistachios and bread. it goes great with the wine. 

On warmer days, they open up the large front window and you can sit either inside or outside and still enjoy the warm summer nights.

Prices are pretty reasonable. 

Chestnut Street is so busy so yes this place gets crowded pretty quickly but it is fun place to grab a drink, meet friends and just enjoy the Marina
author: Whitney S.

description:
Stopped in to shop for a bottle of white.  I figured I'd order a glass of wine to enjoy while I looked at the list.  The service was horrible.

1.  Bartender was not friendly.
2.  Bartender spent most of her time typing on her phone.
3.  She could not answer simple questions about the wines by the glass...varietal...style...etc.

Not only did she lack knowledge of her product but she didn't seem interested in helping or suggesting wines.

Walked to Bin 38 where they were friendly and helpful.  I bought my wine there.
author: Laura G.

description:
Cute wine bar that's easy to walk past in the Marina but worth checking out. The 2 bartenders were really nice and helpful. I was looking for a dry white and they gave me a few tastes (for free) before I decided on one. 
The vibe is very chill. I love the window area. If it's a nice day, try to sit by the window!! Not much seating so don't come with a huge group of people. This would be a great place to take a date before dinner.
author: Sara P.

description:
Comparing them to other wine bars/establishments in the city....

Meh.
author: Tomasz B.

description: Spent last Friday here. I don't know if this place is ran to well. A person named Tara was their gracious hostess. She was a bit tipsy from drinking the profits and giving freebees to some. I was really turned off by her belligerent manners. Anyway, never coming back here. The wine will always be good though..
author: Jorydude r.

description:
My friend brought me to this place place a few weeks back before we had dinner at Delarosa. It was a nice place and I went back again the following week. =)

So far I had 2 different wines that were all very smooth and had excellent flavors. 

1. 2008 Educated Guess Cabernet (I chose this one because I liked the name) - very bold flavors with hints of blackberry & a bit spicy
2. 2008 Balleto Pinot Gris - less dry, fruity, and sweeter version of the normal pinot gris & a smooth finish

I recommended purchasing the wine that you like from there because it is much cheaper than actually drinking it there! (prob a corkage fee?) Also, if you purchase any of the wines listed from the menu, you can get 10% off.

The only thing that I didn't like about the place was that it can get quite busy and the place is kind of small so it was hard to find a place to even stand or get the servers attentions.
author: Alice W.

description: When I visit S.F. I typically stay somewhere in the Marina District.  On my most recent trip, I discovered the CA Wine Merchant for an afternoon glass of wine.  The proprietor, Greg, is a 30+ year veteran of wine with excellent recommendations for wine selections.  We sat next to an open window with a view onto Chestnut St enjoying a beautiful day.  I enjoyed a dry chilled French Rose and my associate exclaimed his pleasure with the Zinfandel from Dry Creek Valley.  Significant retail wine selection and an offer to taste your choice if it is open.  Highly recommend
author: Tim B.

description: Worst pours in the city hands down. Normal to high normal prices with 1/2 sized pours. The food portions are terrible too. I dont know how this place is always packed, but it does have a good location and cool interior.
author: I D.

description:
Small wine shop with wine to drink there as well. 3.5 stars 

Cost to worth it rating: 3 
Return worthiness: yes 

Highlights: 
- Small hallway-like intimate barrel and wine walled spot: has a unique feel to it. Has long bar up front and few seats in the back in the dimly lit area 
- Staff: even though it was busy, came up to us with menus right away and discussed options with us 
- Wines: decent listing with half glass options 

Lowlights: 
- Have to go up slender bit awkward stairs to get to the restroom 

Only spent a small amount of time here but the place has character, so I'd come back and check it out more.
author: Eve K.

description:
California Wine Merchant has great wine, a so-so cheese plate that I would still order regardless, and great patrons.

Also, they get 5 stars because here you can have a cheap abortion by falling down their flight of stairs getting to the bathroom on the 2nd floor.

Or break your neck and have the fire department wheel you out on a gurney. Best date ever.
author: Jaime L.

description: I'm not a huge fan of wine, but we sometimes come in here to meet with friends and I find myself swilling a glass of chilled white wine in my hands.  The recs are helpful and if you are looking to buy a glass of wine for a fancy dinner, etc then head here.  Look out on busy nights as this place gets packed.
author: Carmel U.

description:
Impressive wine collection and a great ambiance makes this place full on almost all nights.
I had to knock off a star for their cheese platter, compared to other wine bars in the area, it simply not impressive.

All in all, recommended for whoever wants to have a chance to try new and exciting wines.
author: Assaf B.

description:
Not really impressed. I thought the wine list was rather limited and the quality of wine fairly low considering it was a bar that specialized in wine... We ordered a couple glasses of an Argentinian Malbec and it was OK. I guess at only $6 a glass I shouldn't have expected much better. (and no, that is not a suggestion that they raise their prices, but that they raise their quality of wine). 

The atmosphere was nice and it turned out to be a good place to start off a date night. Not too loud, easy conversation, and wine. That's always a good start. 

Another comment... The bartenders did not seem like the brightest crayons in the box to me. I guess when all your job entails is to poor wine from one of about twelve choices into a class and hand it to a customer you don't need to be that bright. But these people seemed especially dull. Oh well, I didn't go to hang out with them.

I'm sure I'll be back since its in my neighborhood and because its convenient to start off the evening with. But I hope they get a better wine selection before then.
author: Krista S.

description:
Sitting all the way in the back (which is probably less thank 20 paces from the front door) at a table by myself waiting for friend to get off work, I slowly sipped on my white wine. 

This wine bar was packed. Stuffed. Jam-Packed. So I came in I searched high and low for just one empty bar stool. Just one empty seat. ANYWHERE. And there were none. I sharked my seat after a couple had left, and then my seat was sharked from me when I went to order a second glass. 

Standing at the congested bar, I couldn't even squeeze into a spot at the bar, i was standing behind a stool when the drunken squatter of that chair came and basically pushed me out of the way. Uncomfortable and passive agressive. Awkward. :( 

The service was surprisingly quick, and friendly for how swamped they were. 

So, my general over all experience, (and I feel like this feeling would be much stronger if it weren't so packed as well) is that sitting sipping wine in one of their seats, surrounded by the wood shelves and bottles (much like a cellar, but not as cold.) I felt as if I was being captured on somekind of special edition postage stamp that 50 years from now will be sold for 20x it's value. But again, way to crowded to be enjoyable.
author: nicole r.

description:
My friends all know that I love a good wine bar. This place is no exception. I really enjoyed this place and the guys behind the bar were nice. Well, some of them rather. The shorter guy with the gray hair with the wedding ring was really rather zombie-like. He was just there to pour drinks and not interact with anyone. It may have been a long day for him but his silence and inability to interact with the patrons was really such a downer. 

The place's saving grace was one of the other bartenders. He's the guy with the tattoo sleeves and I told him that he reminded me of Mark Ronson. This bartender was very nice (and kinda cute) and he was also very willing to share a very delicious gingerbread-like cookie. It was very sweet of him and I will return to this wine bar again solely because he was very welcoming. It's unfortunate that he started talking to us right as we were leaving though. Wish he had been serving us from the beginning instead of the downer guy.

The wines are obviously delicious and they have tons of selection here. One thing they should work on though is their cheese plate. Having lived in France, a cheese plate always consisted of at least 5 cheese varying from soft to hard varieties with nuts, fruit and bread.
author: Rylan C.

description:
I love stopping in here on the weekends after a bit of shopping.  They usually have the windows and front door open to let light and fresh air in but the actual bar is a bit dark...I enjoy the contrast.

There is a good selection of wines and sitting at the bar is fun and ever changing as different people stop in.  A bit pricey, but not bad every now and again.
author: Janelle C.

description:
I've been in here several times in the past and had pleasant experiences.

The last two times? Not so much.

The last time I sat at bar for 10 full minutes and had to leave because I couldn't get anyone to take my order. Today I went in and there was one other person. I finally caught the eye of the bartender after about 5 minutes. He continued to work on his computer. I waited a couple more minutes & finally left.

I'm now happily sipping a glass of Prosecco at Delarosa!

Sorry, but they won't get a third chance to ignore me. I'm out.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
I stopped by here with some of my girlfriends a few weeks ago on a Thursday night at 7. We got the very front table that looks out onto chestnut st.  I was so surprised by the wine menu-they had some great options, some well known names too. 

The price points were good and the service was great. It started to get  busy so I'm glad we had a seat. I would most definitely go there again, on a date or with friends. 

My recommendations: Hayman and Hill Russian River Valley Chardonnay & the Matua Valley Sauvingon Blanc. Try the cheese plates too!
author: Heather H.

description: If you want to take a break from the frat scene of the Marina and pretend to be a mature adult, this is the place to come.  With a nice selection of wines by the glass / half bottle / bottle, you can hang at this cozy bar with friends and catch up on all the memories of doing keg stands and causing havoc while you were younger.
author: Chris C.

description: My friends and I passed by this bar on 8-4-13 12am'sh.  The worker gave us the wine menu, as I browsed through, noticed it's expensive.  Just stayed for 5 minutes, got bored and left.
author: Jer W.

description:
I like this place. The bar tender is such a sweet guy and the mood of the room peaceful and intimate. It has a kind of living room feel to it. You feel as though you went to your friends apartment and had a good glass of wine with some friends. 

It is not a hit on place like much of the Marina, but rather a chill low key place to have yummy and affordable wine.
author: Aneliese R.

description:
There is nothing about this place that screams "I AM AWESOME AND FUN!!" I like a little yellin'... which is prob why I don't adore this spot. 

I love wine. Wait, wait... I would give up all other food for wine. Wait, wait... no that's a lie. I would give up everything except dark chocolate and popcorn for wine. (Bible.) So I truly expected more than CWM offered. 

I expected more options. Period. It left a lot to be desired. I prefer to be overwhelmed by the choices I have to make. Meh. My socks weren't knocked off. I want to stress that the options that were available were pretty darn good and they do have quite a few wines that I find are usually difficult to locate, so it's not all bad. 

Simply stated - I don't feel like this would ever be a planned destination spot when desiring a wine bar, BUT I wouldn't pass it up when in the neighborhood if jonesin' for a quick prosecco or zin to throw back... 
In a pinch, it'll do just fine.
author: Kris I.

description:
This place is not what it used to be.  I have lived in the Neighborhood and visited this place on a regular basis.  Not anymore!

The service sucks!   The place smells!   The wine is overpriced!  The owner doesn't care about anything and it is obvious in the staff's behavior.  

What a waste for Chestnut street!  

Maybe its time to open a new wine bar on the block!!  Something with class and style, with plush interior and competitive prices on top California wine.
author: Jay Y.

description: Great wines, awesome service, and nice ambiance if you get there at the right time. One of the better wine bars in the Marina.
author: Matt R.

description:
Great little spot to have a glass of wine with a friendly Napa type atmosphere! 

The staff is very friendly and helpful when it comes to your wine selection. They also have frequent tastings on Monday's for a small price and a new way to experience a local winery. 

They also have a great selection of cheeses to go with your wine! In fact, while we were there, the bartender was cutting up some cheese and gave all three of us a little sample plate! Delicious! 

It is also a great place to people watch as they have a cute little window seat right on Chestnut St.
author: Kelly B.

description:
Stopped in on a lovely sunny SF day to share some wine with friends.  The windows were open and the bar was lively but not crowded on a weekend afternoon.  We looked over the well-edited wine list and chose a bottle of argentine white to share.  Very nice! 

Service was cordial and we chatted amongst ourselves and then with a couple of friendly strangers about the world cup.  I'd give another star if the other bartender was as on point as the first - but he seemed distracted and discourteous.
author: Jaimie M.

description:
I met up with my future sister-in-law at CWM to night cap her bachelorette festivities during this past labor day weekend. We found a perfectly secluded spot at the end of the bar, where we were not obliged to share counter space with the other patrons. I did not really notice the decor of the place because the lights were dimmed so low, but I really appreciated the purse hooks at the bar. I love it when establishments take consideration of this little (but so major!) detail.

As we were reading off the menu, the place filled up around 9:30 p.m.  with a late twenties plus crowd. We had planned to do tastings to "research" for her wedding reception.  I thought cake tasting was fun, but I think taking alcohol notes is the winner here.  CWM is my first experience at a wine bar, and it was pretty cool. I have had my fair share of wineries and tasting rooms, but the wine bar scene is not comparable. There was minimal dialogue with our server, which was completely fine because we were engrossed in our own conversation. Maybe she was being respectful, or maybe this is simply not a place where you should expect to be personable with the other side of the bar. It was a busy night. Glasses were continiously getting filled with the reds and whites.  The other people there seemed to enjoy their time with their own little parties, and no one else looked interested in talking with the pourers either.  Nonetheless our winetender was friendly, and she made great reccomendations as our night progressed from Sauvignon blanc to Cabernet Sauvignon.  

We loved the Spanish Lo Nuevo 2011 Lunares Verdejo and the Napa Roots Run Deep Educated Guess 2011 Cabernet Sauvignon. If these are on your menu tonight (wines are constantly rotating,) make sure at least one of them gets poured.
author: Catherine Ann C.

description:
This place just cracks me up. But, I love it!

The vibe is like something you would find in Tahoe. Laid back staff, friendly but also more of the "bar" v. "wine bar" attitude. 

It feels sometimes like the dive bar of the Wine bars...especially depending on what time you get there. The music is usually something Indie rock like Spoon, Death Cab... The bartenders seem very hipstery. The crowd, well you know it's Marina. I have had many fun times here, despite the fact that they do have the worse cheese plate in the world. The cheese place is basically bread, one kind of non-descript cheese, olives and pistachios.  It's really an "I'm desperately hungry" cheese plate and not an "I want to enjoy cheese" type of cheese plate. 

I like that they have wines by the glass for every budget, starting at 8 bucks a glass to 22 a glass, a good selection and I generally like the place. 

I would give one more star if it weren't for the cheese plate.
author: Kristina A.

description: Good selection of California wines and European too. Maybe it's because I live in wine country but its a relief to be able to drink something Old World once in a while!
author: Marissa A.

description: Love this place. Great wine and value. Can't beat their tasting nights!
author: Jason H.

description: Lame...This place is the size of a shoebox and the crowd is way past it's prime, I would rather get a bottle to go and drink it with the bum in front of Walgreens than hang out here again
author: Scott W.

description:
A friend and I popped in this cute spot on a Friday afternoon, the place was nice and had a decent ambiance.  But we were rushed to give our order to the bartender and she was not busy at all.  

The wine was excellent, but the service was really disappointing.  Upon closing my tab the young girl literally chucked my credit card at me.  As we exited and were discussing our poor service a couple overheard us and shared the same bad service.  I assumed she just wasn't giving us service because she thought we were young and wouldn't take care of her, but I have worked in the service industry and feel am a very good tipper if it's deserved.

Needless to stay but I won't be returning.
author: meagan M.

description: Retail prices for the wine were 75% more expensive than a search on the internet. Be care for visiting an purchasing retail bottles there. Check online prices for any bottle you are thinking of purchasing outside of the wines they are pouring for tasting which are the same as retail. The high end wines are much for expensive than current market prices
author: Brian W.

description:
Staff is extremely knowledgeable and the wines are awesome.  This place is very busy and has a vibe that makes it easy to mingle.

I like design inside; its everything a wine bar should be - 

Just go and hang out, drink a bunch of wine and be merry!
author: Alexis B.

description:
I liked this place. They have a great selection and reasonable prices for the wine you are getting. I also love the fact that you can get a wine flight instead of a whole glass for about half the price. Staff was nice and attentive.

Only downside is it is in the Marina (ha!) and can get pretty crowded.
author: Karen S.

description:
The wine is great here. 

But it's pretty small and usually filled with drunk cougars and grey-haired men. Not sure why that is, but the two times I've been, I've been aggressively hit on by guys twice my age.

Twenty-something girls beware....
author: Julie V.

description:
I always pass by California Wine Merchant while running errands on Chestnut. Although it's one of my roomie's favorite wine bars, I went in for the first time the other night. Twas happenin' in there!

I really appreciate how they rotate their featured wines, daily. It's makes the place very neighborhood friendly, as you know there are lots of choices, you'll never get bored. (lets be honest, I'm never bored with wine).

While my glass of mixed reds (Petite Syrah, Zin, Syrah) did not live up to my expectations, I will be back. The service is extremely friendly and warm and the vibe is, well, happenin'!
author: Laura D.

description: I think this is my favorite wine bar in the city. The staff are always pleasant and knowledgeable about the wines and I love that you can purchase wines to take home. Definitely not the cheapest place to taste but look at where they are located, the Marina. Sometimes the clientele can get a bit interesting but for the most part everyone is pretty much into drinking their wine and enjoying their company. Highly recommend stopping by.
author: Heather L.

description:
I used to buy all of my wine at the old California Wine Merchant on Pierce Street.  Greg & Debra are great people and really know their wine.  I'm very happy for them that their "new" store is doing so well.

I do miss the old store.  I'd pop in for a glass of wine, but, it's always packed these days.  But, I still go when I want to buy a good bottle of wine.  The people who work there are always knowledgeable and very helpful and I never leave with a bottle of wine that I don't like.  My friends are always happy to have me over for dinner because they know I'll bring a good bottle of vino.... well, I hope it's for the company as well ;)

This is the place to come if you want to buy a very special bottle of wine.
author: Nancy H.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review on the Wine Merchant yet.  

I give it all 5 stars because this is my kind of place.  Wine, convenient, and good friends.  Yes, I'm a Marina girl...that's just how it goes.  Because of that, I can come here often, get a seat, and have the bartenders who know me and what I like (lots of cherry, hint of smoke, no pepper) will pick a great wine for me.  Is it pricey? Yes.  But for me a great glass is to savor, not down.  (If that is my mood, buy the bottle of prosecco and go to town.)  

I have made good friends here, and my old friends that come with me always enjoy the night.  It's casual fun, with great people watching.  And the guys can go to the Horseshoe across the street and have their guy time....we don't all need to be attached at the hip all the time...right?
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Best wine bar in the country imho--the crowd is pretty mellow most of the time.  Avoid on weekends unless you can get there early.  The gold diggers and douche bag crowd usually show up around 7 or so.  

If you have to wear a suit every day and you come here after work, at least loosen your tie or take off your jacket.  Otherwise it starts to look a little weird.

If you don't like wine, then please don't come here.  Its a wine bar fer chrissakes.  Circa and Thirsty Pig are just a few paces in either direction and will gladly cater to your cosmo/jack daniesl/attention whore needs.
author: T H.

description:
Stopped by here with a friend on a Saturday night because we were looking for a place that was a bit more classy and not so crowded and congested. The seats were definitely filled and one of the bartenders... err.. no.. wine connoisseurs? ... wine pourers?... anyway, PEOPLE who work there got us two seats near some of the bottles towards the back. It was nice and he let us know ... the guys at the counter are a little weird anyway... It was a good spot to chill and peruse their extensive wine menu until we got our wine. Some people left the counter and we swooooped their spots.

The worst part about this place is that they really didn't have any of my favorite wines. I'm pretty sure every time I would ask them for something that I wanted (and didn't see on the menu right away), they were like.. oh we're out OR oh... we don't carry that. I thought that, in the marina, they would have special wines and not just your run of the mill reds and whites. I really just like what tastes good - I really am not snobby or know enough to say what flavors are in each wine... but I just remember the names of good wine.. like.. Barberas, Viognier, Gewurtztraminer, Rose, etc. They were either out of what I wanted or didn't carry them. What, really?!

The upside to this is that I would get tastings of some wines that they did have that were similar to what I wanted because they didnt have what I actually wanted. I got to have miniature tastings of a lot of different wines but I couldn't really enjoy what I wanted... For a wine specialty place, I expected a bit more. Maybe that's my bad. It could have also just been that they were so popular and busy that they ran out of everything! I guess if you are starting out with wine, you could try this place out and see what kinds you like.
author: Joyce D.

description:
I had the worse experience at this place last night... I've never been treated so badly any venue before.  It wasn't a busy night, but the bar tender ignored me for a good 10 minutes while he took phone calls and chatted with other people at the bar.  Then, when I politely  called him out on it, he yelled at me and literally kicked my friend and I out of the bar, waving his hands in the air saying "I refuse to serve you! Get out! Get out of here!" 

It was unbelievable. A number of witnesses were shocked, as he threatened to kick them out as well. I know it's hard to believe, but I'm not exaggerating.  I'm still shocked myself...

Go to Nectar around the corner, better wine list and outstanding service.
author: F S.

description: Meh.  The wines are just OK.  Some great labels mixed in with obscure wines.  I got the hip vibe from the music and staff.  They were not especially friendly and I felt like it was a privileged to have a glass of wine here.  The attitude does not transmit to the wine or decor.  Looks like an old bar that they put some bottles in - not much work on the interior, like they have not really invested in their venture.  Not sure id come back.
author: R P.

description:
This place needs to kick out jerks when they're acting up, threatening and insulting.
Even after three of us complained about this guy the bartender wouldn't remove him.
There are plenty of over priced wine bars to not have to deal with this one.
author: Ace s.

description:
Michelle and I came in here for a quick glass of wine before dinner, Friday night. Every seat at the bar was occupied and only standing room to enjoy our fantastic glass of Australian Grenache (sp?). 
Love how the menu changes and you can buy bottles there. Cool ambiance, would love to come back when it's not so busy, to try other great wines.
author: DayDay D.

description:
Would you like another glass of red zinfandel?  Why, certainly.  

I dig this place.  It's my go-to-Friday-night-need-a-glass-of-wine-and-talk place.   The bar is cozy; a few tables and chairs in the back, and a bunch of stools along the front of the bar.   It gets crowded pretty fast, so I make a beeline for the back and nab the same table with loose stools near the stairs that lead to the upstairs bathroom.  

The crowd:  mostly older working professionals.  Perfect for a Friday night.  No fuss, no muss.  

The wine selection isn't too shabby.  The tasting menu is obviously cheaper ranging from $6-9 dollars while whole glasses can be upwards of $20+.    But, you can find some great wines for around $9/glass.   I recommend the cab or the Merlot if you like red.  And a Riesling if you prefer a sweeter white.  

The beer selection is your basic imports: Heinekein, Sam Adams, etc.  

It's the perfect spot to drink a little vino and catch up on weekly whoseits and whatsits with the girlfriends.
author: Soo Jin K.

description:
Came here after walking around the marina... .we got "thirsty" so we stopped in and stayed... 

Bartenders were knowledgeable about the wines they were pouring and we did meet some interesting folks. Definitely a chill place to sit around and drink with your friends. 

I love how they note what you drink on a post it note! 

I'll be back!
author: Julie F.

description:
Great wine spot on Chestnut. Cozy and intimate atmosphere with pleasant and knowledgeable bartenders. 

There is limited seating, so just saddle up the the bar. They provide a shorter wine list which I appreciated--not overwhelming at all.  The glasses are between $8-$18 which was very reasonable for the quality of wine. 

I tipped back quite a few glasses and had a great time!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
This place is super cute and has a great selection of wine. However, it's always packed in the evenings and there really aren't a lot of places to sit and talk. 

Pros
- Great wine
- Nice selection
- Knowledgeable staff

Cons
- Crowded
- Lack of seating
- Slow service
author: Marissa P.

description: Unfortunately this was not a great first time experience. Being from Los Angeles and hearing decent things about marina establishments this one fell far from the apple tree. I'll summarize, decor: great, wine selection:  great, prices: outrageous, customer service: McDonald's is better. Okay so on that note let me explain. Neither myself nor the people that I was near were offered suggestions on any of the wine selection. In fact when the menu was dropped and asked may we help you all of a sudden the bartender sprinted outside and didn't even offer suggestion or an explanation for that completely rude. Did i mention she didn't return? After a couple glasses of wine asked for some glasses of water and with rolling eyes received it two different sized glasses and of course no ice just plain water. At the end  I was asked by the bartender tonight would you like the check?  yes, all of a sudden she comes back with it charged to one credit card we were going split it. Very unprofessional just not an experience that I think was deemed a place that I would  recommend or come back to. Which is unfortunate because the place has great potential.  Save the time said the money save the anguish and save embarrassment of trying to show someone a good spot. I was actually recommended by the person I was with to go here and even she was offended. Hate giving these types reviews but I feel in our society with social media, experiences are meant to be spoken about and businesses need to understand that we as a society have the opportunity to either glorify them or speak the truth.
author: Sean B.

description:
Overall this place is small, but I would have to say that it's not just about the place that makes the venue, it's the staff who I really review and what makes a visit memorable or pleasurable.

This place definitely has a feel of a wine cellar, the marina locals spot, rubbing elbows, mixer type place to be.  Clean and it somewhat reminds me of being somewhere in Napa or St. Helena at some local mini version winery.  They serve mini bite's small assortment of cheese, bread, truffles, olive's etc...not much on the menu to eat but it gets the alcohol soaked if you are planning to hang for the evening and enjoy a couple glass.

Music system is lacking since it's a bit too loud and you can't hear what's playing. Restroom is upstairs along a narrow steep stairs, so be careful if you've had one too many to drink. Staff is very friendly and warm.

Nice date spot by the window area where it opens wide to the street and you can people watch. It's a down tempo style place to be if you're not up for the craziness the Marina bar's and lounges has to offer.
author: Jules V.

description:
Was visiting San Fran with my GF and happened by this spot because the place that had been recommended was not open yet.   We were advised it was a bit on the yuppish side and a more happening spot.  Not so much the chill local.    

We caught a beautiful afternoon and a few barstools by the street side open window.

The best part was how great Brandt (our bartender was).  He made our experience fantastic.  We are wine novices and he was awesome. Not sure if all the staff is that way but call and check his hours.  When he is working enjoy!

Great Place!
author: jeremy L.

description: I enjoyed this smaller, hole in the wall wine bar. Service was really friendly and the wine was delicious. Seems like a good place to stop in for a relaxed drink, especially in the mix of a neighborhood like the Marina.
author: Rachel R.

description: Um, $22 for a glass of wine. For that I expect more than a wooden bar stool and at least a hook for my purse under the bar.
author: Jessica G.

description: Stopped in here for a glass with my hubby before my dinner at home in the slow-cooker was ready. They have a number of wines and price ranges to choose from on their menu, and you can either order a bottle, glass, or a taste. I think a "taste" is a brilliant idea. For someone like me who cannot switch up her alcohols and needs to stick to either white or red during her night out, this is the perfect wine bar to come to after dinner. If you don't want another full glass of wine but don't want to be a party pooper, just order a "taste!" Anyway, aside from great wines, you can also indulge in a cheese plate or a bowl of pistachios. We thoroughly enjoyed our time but the reason I am not giving it five stars is because we did not experience the same service the first time we dropped in. The first time we came in we waited for at least 15 minutes before we were acknowledged. It was annoying. I am glad we gave it a second try though nd I look forward to bringing my wine savvy family back to California Wine Merchant.
author: Kelsey K.

description:
Who knew the Marina had two kick ass wine bars within spitting distance of each other?  Had Nectar not been closed for a private event, and had my lovely girl date not immediately rerouted us to CWM, I would've missed out.
I had already had three glasses of wine with an amazing meal before heading over here, so I was in a good mood.  Our bartender was adorable and great and made fantastic recommendations, and let us try samples of things before committing (even though his suggestions were spot on).  

Kudos for helping us extend a lovely and long overdue night catching up; double kudos to our friendly Georgian bar mate that told us we were beautiful and bought us both a glass of wine.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I'm definitely a fan of California Wine Merchant! Here's why: 1) Cozy and friendly ambiance. I love how the large window brings in much sunlight into the bar. 2) Great selection of wine. Sometimes a larger wine offering makes ordering too difficult. 3) Staff is awesome! Great with suggestions, and overall friendly and attentive. 

My companion and I enjoyed two glasses; I tried two of the pinot noirs and she had two whites. All were very decently priced..and awesome they offer tastings too! The cheese platter was a perfect amount of food, including pistachios, olives, cheese and slices of bread. Debating on whether or not we wanted something sweet, one of the staff decided for us and on the house offered us a few of the chocolate candies. Nice! Totally hit the spot! 

I will definitely go back to California Wine Merchant! Quaint, fun wine bar perfect for after work hours and apparently into the night (closes at 2:00am).
author: Marie B.

description:
Fantastic place.   Very social, fine wines, reasonably priced.  

I am thrilled for the owner Greg that his business is such a success.  
He truly deserves it.
author: Art A.

description: I like the wood wall decor and the barrel tables. Aside from that, I don't like this place at all. The white wine we had wasn't served at the right temperature (the bartenders didn't even care when we informed them of this fact) and the service overall was terrible. Not to mention that some of the wines are definitely overpriced. I will be taking my business elsewhere.
author: Amy F.

description:
I walk in, already nervous for many reasons on many levels:
1.) I arrived in a my lamest gear--my poofy jacket from Forever-Hoochie that I always get obnoxious comments on. It's not my fault I can't afford a "Fall Jacket" right now.

2.) I was in the Marina, which automatically shoots my self-esteem down to about a 3 on a scale of 10. I don't own a Beamer, I left my pearls at home, and right about now I was craving some J in the B.

I step in and see my friends sitting in a corner, practically shoved next to a group of male-cougars. Foul. 

I immediately demand that my friend Katie and I hit the bar and booze up to help dull the pain. I get my menu and so does she. Katie of course orders a beer (atta girl) and I order the lamest glass of Reisling (wine snobs submit your judgment now). 

And here's where it gets weird. The bartender takes out a post-it, writes a large "X" on the paper and an arrow pointing toward the X and then scratches the word "GUM". It took me a minute to register what he wanted me to do, as he stared blankly at me. I succumb and take my gum out of my mouth, feeling like I was getting busted for chewing gum in the 2nd grade during class. I hang my head, crumpled the piece of paper and give it back to him.

I snatch my wine from him, and don't tip. Yeah you heard me. I'm THAT bold.

I go back to my table and tell my story, tears in my eyes from embarrassment. Asshole! Jerk! How could he do that to you!? I put my sunglasses on aka my haterblockers and proceed to throw back my sweet-ass Reisling.
