We proceed to make an agreement that I will write a terrible yelp review and that I hated this place already so much that I will tell every person I have ever encountered not to patron this place for the humiliation and travesty their bartender has committed.

A few minutes later, after wallowing in Victimville, population me, the same bartender walks up with another glass of wine.

"I was just trying to beat you to the punch. I wasn't trying to be condescending--I swear. I just thought you might want to spit out your gum before you drank you wine".

Asshole=me

Thankyou, I mumble. I grab the wine and tell him how embarrassed he made me feel. He said he's done that to a million other people and no one has taken it like me. Guess I'm a freak. Guess I'm an oversensitive, overdramatic freak of the emotional world. 

I hunch down, pound my second glass of wine and think about what a bonehead I am.

It still sucks. So there. F California Wine Merchant.
author: Lexi B.

description:
It was looking to be a perfect cure for a dreary Monday evening: one cozy atmosphere, one lovely bottle of merlot and one Raider of the Visual Arts.

Along with our glasses, our canvas was filling up with colorful conversation and soft laughter, until the sommelier/bartender dropped the c-bomb right in the middle of the landscape.

 A. CORKAGE. Fee. To. A.  Bottle. We. Bought. There. From. Them. On. Freaking. Site. Un. Freaking. Believable. 

Because its cozy casual atmosphere has been the backdrop of many  3D technicolor memories, I've swallowed a lot of their malarky since they've opened their doors: charging $6.75 for a small taste; an arrogant owner dressing down  his staff; and a list with pretentiously over-priced choices. 

The Bratty Brainiac, the Diva Doc and I have celebrated life's heavenly highs and nursed our hellish lows here. And in fact, I met my favorite Daddy one night while he and his posse were on the prowl.

But unfortunately, this experience left me with one case of sour grapes too many. 

Overall: Paint me red, Raider and put a Cork in this place.
author: CharliesAngel L.

description:
Great selection of wines...charming atmosphere.  ALWAYS packed.

But, the people here tonight were the quintessential snobby Marina type.  More than I've ever experienced at any other Marina establishment, actually.  I had more than one altercation with pushy, posh and rude patrons of this wine bar.

However, that shouldn't reflect what this business stands for.  They had all different types of wines that were appealing to my group and I, and the employees seemed like they actually cared about the experience their customers were having.  

But the crowd?  Please.  Bitch, I know I'm sitting here alone, but my friends are outside smoking, OK?  I don't need elevator eyes right now- take your skanky, stilletto/miniskirt on a Wednesday ass out of my face.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
I really liked CWM.

It's a small space, but big enough to enjoy yourself.  Just check at the door - - - if it's too crowded, come back another time.

CWM has a really big selection of available wines, and really good service, too.  The price range for the bottles is vast - - from quite economical to "hopefully one day, I, too, can drink this stuff" bottles.  We had a really nice bottle of C-------- - a name I cannot remember at this time but our wine freak friend picked it out - - and it was truly delicious and smooth.  Loved it.

The stools are comfortable and the mood is nice in here.  It's a good location at which to socialize with folks you don't know, and the people who come in here are apparently ready to gab, as I found out within 2 minutes of being in here.  From local Marina folk to tourists - - CWM plays host to a variety of folks, and who you find in here will solely depend on your luck.

The price per glass was a bit steeper than other wine bars I have been to, but based on the few tastes I had, I'm inclined to think that they have a better, classier selection than other wine bars.

I really like Amelie, another wine bar in SF, as well as CAV Wine Bar - - and CWM gives both a good run for their money.  I think CWM has a better selection - - Amelie has better ambience and layout - - and CAV has better appetizers and food.


All in all, CWM is a place I will definitely frequent from here on when I am wanting a good bottle, or a topnotch glass of wine.
author: Grace K.

description: How many times have you gone to a wine bar, loved the wine you were drinking sooooo much that you wanted to take it home... but its a wine bar so you cant. Well this place solves that age old problem. You can get tipsy on some GREAT wine ( as they have a wonderful list) and then... then... THEN.... you can buy a bottle and bring it home ( or to the movie theatre next door, i mean thats what i would do )
author: douglas B.

description:
If you only like high-end California wines, this is the place for you.  If you decide that $15 for a glass of wine that retails for $29 is a little steep, no problem - you can opt for a taste at $7.50.  If you like to pay $7.50 for a pour as shallow as a Napa tasting room, you've hit paydirt.  And if you like your overpriced and underpoured wine to be served with a healthy dose of condescension, this must be nirvana.

One star for the wine selection.  An added star for calling this arrogant ass next to me on looking like Michael Douglas in the Wonder Boys.  And no, it wasn't Michael Chabon.
author: mcmalaprop ..

description:
California Wine Merchant... hmm just from thinking about the name.... what do you expect?
Definitely more than one or two sauvignon blancs on the menu. Especially if you are only up for *a* glass. Also the white wine was a bit too warm for my taste.
author: Doro P.

description:
I am disappointed with the snotty staff.  These guys are full of themselves.

Good selection and cute little spot but with that sort of attitude they sure won't get my money.  I'll take my money elsewhere.
author: Emmy d.

description:
Like everyone else, I'll say it...it's a bar, with wine.  I found the wine to be fairly good.  They did run out of Pinot Noir while we were there, which was interesting as it is the "it wine" of the moment according to certain publications.  I also felt the Cab we ordered was better, which I'd never say as generally I prefer Pinot...

The music was on the right track after beck ended...because then it got into sexier songs...

massive attack + two glasses of wine = hot.  I think we can all agree a wine bar is a place that should be sexy.

it's a nice place to stop by when you are in the hood, I'd say.  I will be going back, if only in hopes of a repeat performance...but this time with the Cab.
author: Jess S.

description: Decent place to pick up a bottle of wine or just hang out for a few. None-pretentious and no frills. The wine selection is good and the staff friendly. However, not a place to go if you like to pair wine with food--they have a selection of cheeses served out of Gladware..not much else. Go after dinner of perhaps an for an afternoon delight..
author: Mimi T.

description:
OK To hang out, but PLLLLEASE - the wines they serve sell for $12 a BOTTLE at BevMo - and they charge $12 a GLASS !!!           
Lousy, way overpriced wines, ok spot to sit and talk.
author: chris b.

description: I came here, in the middle of the day on a weekday, expressly to buy wine. It took a while for anyone to greet me (the folks working there seemed busy with wine sales guys). After several minutes someone did approach and I explained my intention and was offered numerous choices that fit within my parameters. Being able to taste the recommended wines would have upped the level of my experience, but as it was, I left pleased.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Went to the CA Wine Merchant for the first time last night after Izzy's and was modestly impressed with the wine selections.

The atmosphere is pretty casual and comfortable and the pourers are friendly and helpful.

I would have given them 4 stars if it weren't for 2 things.

1.  When I went to the restroom it looked like someone's St. Bernard had gone for a dip and then shaken himself dry in the bathroom.  I was almost afraid to go in there was so much water everywhere.  I do have to append this note because even though I did get to experience the wet dog runoff, the next time I was up the bathroom was clean - so staff did have their act together and it was more a problem with a patron than with CA Wine Merchant.

2.  When comparing the the bottle price with the / glass price of their dryest champagne I noted that the bottle was $40 and a glass was $17.  We had reason to celebrate and even with corkage, we would come out way ahead by buying the bottle and there seemed to be some question if this was acceptable for us to do - buy a bottle and open it and consume it right there.

The last thing I would warn folks about is that if you have to use the bathroom, stay sober.  I mean, stay sober anyway, but especially if you are here and expect to have to use the facilities.  The steps are skinny and steep and I watched one drunk fool try to navigate them with a bad outcome.  There were no injuries, but he ended up sitting on the stairs and everyone below him and above him was trapped for a few minutes while he regained his bearings.  I don't know who had it worse, those like myself trapped upstairs away from our drinks or those downstairs trying unsuccessfully to get to the bathroom.  :-)
author: Jonathan D.

description:
A no-frills kind of place which is good. Overall, it comes down to the company you keep in my opinion. A pretty decent selection of wines with a couple of very nice picks from T-Vine Wines. Our servers were nice and may have been a little more attentive. I would have liked to have been told that a "taste" of something is actually different from "tasting" a wine to see if I wanted to buy a glass. Despite being on the menu, the bartenders should point this out to people.

I agree with a few reviewers that this place does have more of a "bar" feel then a wine bar atmosphere, if there is such a thing. I do like the place though and would certainly go back if friends wanted to go. Go here on a sunny weekend day and sit in the window. It's a great place to people watch!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
Not impressed at all.  Had few glasses of wine here, but the server did not change my glass for the second pour!  And it was for a different wine!!

The cheese plate was just cut-up of plain, for-sandwich cheese (most likely regular white cheddar that you can get from any supermarket) along with pistachio and olives.  Yes, it was only $6, but Absinthe also offers one excellent, gourmet cheese for $6, along with tasty accompaniments.

And the mark-up!  I saw that one of the wines by glass was costing almost what you pay for the full bottle at K&L.
author: Mami T.

description:
The downside of this place is the seating is pretty limited, especially on the weekends. We have been very lucky to score two seats at the bar on our first visit, and a table near the window on a Saturday evening.  

I think the "by the glass" selection is pretty extensive and I like the fact you can order 1/2 glasses (called "taste") in case you want a little more variety and still stick to one glass. ;-)

The staff is very nice, knowledgeable and always have great suggestions.  I also think this place attracts a friendly crowd -not something most people would expect in the Marina.
author: Carla R.

description:
My friend and I went here to get a a relaxing glass or two of wine one night after a busy day of school and work.  We show up, and sit down and the girl behind the counter gives us menus.  So we looked over the menus, and withen about 3 minutes we knew exactly what we wanted.  We were carrying on chatting expecting the girl to see that we were done looking at the menus, and take our order.  After about 10 minutes, we began getting annoyed because not only had the girl NOT asked us what we wanted, but she was walking around behind the counter on her personal CELL PHONE.  

Eventually she took our order, and we drank our wine, but the girl behind the counter must have taken 3-5 personal calls during our 30 minute stay.  

We found that very unprofessional... and not to mention KIND of annoying when we just wanted to order.

Wine was good, good selection. thats why 2 stars. horrible service.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Greg O'Flynn and his wife Debbie have been in the wine business for decades.  Formerly on Pierce Street (where the Sloat Garden Center is currently found), Greg built his reputation by identifying up-and-coming producers of California wines, especially Zinfandel.  His portfolio represents a wide range of styles and regions, as well as his own deep roots in our state's wine business.

Both the wine shop and the wine bar are staffed by knowledgeable people, though the turnover is, as with most retail businesses, rather frustrating.  Both for the owner and for patrons who develop a rapport with given staff members.  One of the few wine bars with open access to the sidewalk via the front windows, which is not quite but almost as much fun as a Parisian bistro!
author: Dave C.

description:
the wine bar has a cute ambiance but prices are way oooofffffff!
You can't find anything decent from Napa or Sonoma below $40...This place is a rip off thanks to its owner Greg O'Flynn!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
The guy has dollar signs written all over his face when he speaks to you, I have never met a guy that I disliked that much at a wine bar, before and after drinking.
That says it all.
author: bob b.

description:
In my opinion, one of the most under rated wine bars in the Marina. Great wine, some beer, reasonably priced, great staff and crowd.

I have come here on a number of occasions for get togethers, b day parties and just some good old drinking and have always had an amazing time.

Friendly and awesome wine/bar tenders, great selection of wine and very reasonable pricing. I have been here many-a-times when I thought the bill was gonna kill me only to be pleasantly surprised.

A little small but opens up a little in the back. Always pretty busy with a decent local crowd. The only drawback: I can't remember how many times I almost killed myself going up/down the stairs to go to the bathroom (yes, the alcohol probably had something to do with it).
author: Rob H.

description:
I have to admit - I wavered between two or three stars on this place.  

Pros:
*Finding a nicely focused wine list (all CA of course)
*drinking delicious by-the-glass selections (and in tasting pour or full glass sizes)
*a couple of friends like this place enough to knock off work early in order to score the coveted window table, which is fabulous on nice nights

Cons:
*having someone reach through the middle of my conversation to select a bottle of Pinot (since the bar and shop are the same space)
*having to jump up and down to get service almost every time I've been here
*listening to the high-pitched giggling (or, heaven help me - the marina mating call) on a packed night - and there are so many packed nights here.

I really only come here if friends suggest it.  So, it has to be two stars - too annoying, too little service and way too much high-pitched giggling.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
Been here twice and both times with my Colorado import Law School buddy Emma.  First time we were here the bartender totally took care of us.  Aside from what we ordered he kept pouring us tasting portions of wine and had us guess what we just tasted...fun game but we failed miserably!!
Second time was on a weekend night and it was packed but the service was still just as good.  We were excited that they had on the menu T-vine red (syrah) which made my husband happy!!  I really love their tasting selection and Pey-Marin, which has been on the menu both times I've been there, has been my lingering favorite.
The service here is great...their cheese platter is average...and their wine selection i yummy!!
author: Karen B.

description:
This place was packed when we strolled by last night so we thought we would drop in for a glass of wine.  The older gentleman bartender was very friendly and it was easy to get service.  We ordered a cabernet and a malbec, and we found them both to be pretty horrible.   After standing for 15 minutes, we grabbed a seat at the front of the bar so we could catch a nice breeze.  It was very comfortable.  

I ordered a muscat canelli because I was craving something sweet, and then my experience was quite enjoyable.  If I found another tolerable wine, I think this would be a great place to relax on a summer evening.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Went here on a whim this past saturday afternoon by myself.  It's usually supercrowded and a place to people watch, but I managed to get in before the big crowds descended.  

They have a great variety of wines mainly West Coast, but to be able to taste the elite names by the glass 
I found the staff down-to-earth and extremely personable(Thanks Kellly for your recommendations). 

I've been back on a few occasions on monday night tastings and found the environment very approachable and chill..

I'll compare my experience with PressClub(for tasting fine wine and forgetting your wallet), Amelie(nice scene at night) and Bacchus(super small).
Since it was a previous dive bar, it retains its charm(small, personable, easy to start conversations).
author: Peter F.

description: I know this place is in the Marina so you may think it draws a certain type of crowed, but I swear all the Marinates somewhow mellow out and grow up in this place.  I've been here many times, day, night,  happy hour and I have always had a great time.  The Bartenders know their wine, can make good recommendations and are always happy to take your order and serve you a glass of wine.
author: Inga W.

description: Not a bad selection overall, but nothing that really jumps out at you. It might be due to the fact that the owner is dated. Missing some of the great pinots from the North Coast. Generic overall.  Too many other great wine shops in the city. Lackluster in many ways.
author: Sean R.

description:
Ahhh, "Winestar!"

CWM is a great place for happy hour.  It's a great place for pre-dinner drinks.  It's a great place for post-dinner drinks.  It's a great place for a leisurely afternoon drink.  I have a good time every time I go here.  I love the open window so you can people watch.  It's crowded almost all the time, so be prepared.  It can be very hard to find a seat. Despite it's crowdedness, it's still great and this place never disappoints.

ps- the "tastes" as opposed to full glasses are still very generous pours.
author: Angie C.

description:
Why do I love this place? Because it is what a wine bar should be! 
We are too consumed with material things. One place trying to out do another or one person trying to over impress another and yada..yada..yada... I've had nothing but great times here! It's small but oh so very quaint. Just a lovely place. Walk around the rooms to check out the wine selection. Sit inside (with your cigie hanging out the open windows) and enjoy your vino. Get there early, the place gets crowded rather quickly.
author: Audrey S.

description:
When you graduate from going to Bar None, you come here.

Where you feel more sophisticated because you dropped $18 on a glass of genovese wine versus $1.50 on a pint of good ol' Natural Light.  But at the end of the night, you just wanted to get your fade on.  You shed the neon wristbands for an actual watch or bracelet and finally comb your hair.  A scent is worn and it's not Tag or Stetson.  Ok, don't lie, there are some of you young'uns sporting the Old Spice.  Old Spice DID NOT make a comeback.  Don't let the 'cool' commercials fool you.

By the way, the place is a bar in sheep's clothing.  It's get pretty crackin' by night, so be prepared to stand unless you're an early drunk.  The wine selection there is actually quite impressive.  They have a nice stock of everything you need.  They even boast weekday tastings from local wineries, which is a plus.  The staff is always helpful and cheery (before the rush) and I believe they can order wine direct, if needed.

They serve a standard pairing dish, which is nice.  Cheese / fruit / nut plate.  Not bad.  Wish they had more snacks, however.  But it works.

If you're lucky, score the front window seat.  You can people watch and poke fun, all at the same time.  Plus it gets hot, if you're deep inside.  Definitely a nice place to pop in for a few glasses as a warm-up or a nightcap.  But again, the place gets really packed on weekends, so be prepared to yell.

And, they even serve a small selection of beers for those of you that just haven't made the grade yet.
author: Isaac L.

description:
My friend owns a wine bar so when we stopped in after eating at A16, the wines immediately caught our eye.  There are some seriously heavy hitters on the wall.  Krupp, Dumol, Biale, Corison,  Sea Smoke, Novy, Turley, Layer Cake, Flowers, and those are mainly only Reds.

By the glass and trust me/us on this because we know:  Hitching Post Pinot!  Did you see Sideways?  Great juice!  Sparkling:  Gruet N/V Brut - New Mexico. (yes, New Mexico but it's GOOD)  Whites:  Ancien Sauvignon Blanc and I'm 99% sure they offered Walter Hansel Chardonnay!  You'll thank me later.

Ask for Brant behind the bar.  Cool guy, tells funny stories and knows his wines!  I'd go back in a nano-second if I lived close.  I can see how this would be an interesting place to....ahhh...meet someone new and Bin 38 was too crowded or pretentious for ya.
author: Steven R.

description: Great little place with a wonderful selection of wine and a nice atmosphere. The table by the window is perfect for people watching (saw an infamous Giants closer strolling down Chestnut last night!)
author: Alexandra B.

description: I stopped by this bar while in the Marina recently. It's an intimate setting with an excellent wine selection. The cheese plate was awesome. The service was professional and the blonde bartender helped pick out a perfect Pinot for my taste. I'll definitely be back here.
author: James B.

description:
I was brought here against my will by some buddies. By the time I arrived they'd carved out a nice niche at the bar and had multiple glasses in front of them. They're regulars so the guy behind the bar ( aka jerk who never serves me when I come in alone) knew them and was very attentive. 

Okay California Wine Merchant, maybe my first impression(s) were a little misguided. Once you're in and settled the place is actually quite nice. The dim lighting makes everyone really attractive, too. Bonus play!
author: Rachael W.

description:
I love this place! You'll find me there every Saturday night!

Everywhere else in the Marina has become really lame (*cough* Matrix *cough*)

I've never had a bad glass of wine here and love how it is really cosy, yet not "packed" like everything else in the area.

Bottle prices are reasonable and have a $15 corkage fee.
author: CK Y.

description: Love this place. I don't think you can fault a bar for the crowd. The wine list is obviously great, the atmosphere is fabulous and it's a perfect location. The prices are average for a wine bar on SF (i.e. more than we all wish we were paying, but wither move or stop complaining).  Plus, Tom is the best!
author: Joey E.

description:
So if you want a California Wine this is the place to go.  You can find an amazing selection of Reds and Whites from all over California here.  I usually get a Cabernet or Zin here.  

The cheese plate and pistachios are delicious.  

The reason I gave it 3 stars and not 4 is more because of atmosphere.  I've met some interesting people but if you want an Orange County vibe of people who think they've made it to the city.  This is it.  It's very much the whitest you can get and a meat market. 

I will come back here since my friend is in the hood and when I'm ever in the Marina I do generally stop by.  They always remember me which is nice.  Overall the staff has always been friendly.  I've been going there on and off for the last couple years.
author: Sabrina A.

description: Pretty low key place for a glass of wine. The staff is friendly and there's a good selection by the glass. The cheese plate is pretty is decent. It's always packed so it's sometimes hard to get a table or spot at the bar. This is my go-to place for a glass of wine in the Marina.
author: Gina C.

description:
Me likey.  

Cool place, nice vibe inside.  I had a really nice Malbec that was really well priced.  The Seattle "truffles" aren't exactly truffles in my mind, but still good chocolate.  One of the bartenders there, Brant, is super duper nice.  

The only downer is that by the open window out front, you can sit right there and smoke.  Well, it's a great thing if you smoke, but not so great if you don't and it's blowing toward you while you're seated at the bar.  Still, I am a fan.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Such a cute little place! The place itself had a  long bar with seating for people to sit at and taste wines, a back area and a front little nook by the window.  The staff was nice, and the wine list was super extensive.  It was a little bit expensive, but for the company and the atmosphere, I really didn't mind.  I just wasn't going to be going home super drunk.  

I had a few sparking wines, and the bread and cheese platter which though small, did the trick.  This was a great place to sit and hang out and catch up with a small group of friends.  It was warm and inviting and who wouldn't want to sit amongst a room full of shelves and shelves of wine?  

We closed the place down we liked it so much.  I think I may have found a new hang out in the Marina.
author: Denise B.

description:
They have a nice selection and warm atmosphere, but the prices are much higher than my local wine shop... and on top of that they have a corkage fee even if you purchase a bottle on site?

I am all FOR PROFIT, but the corkage fee coupled with higher prices doesn't sit well with this little lass.
author: Nenette Y.

description: Great neighborhood wine bar.  Guys, this is the only bar that has more girls than guys!  On a bad night, the guy to girl ratio is 50/50.  On a good night, 25/75 at its worst!  If you're looking to pick up chicks, this is the place to go!;-) Girls, it's a great place to relax with your girl friends and if you don't know much about wine, the servers can help you out.  Friendliest people you'll ever meet!
author: My Loan J.

description:
My friend and I popped in here on a Saturday night to enjoy a glass while we waited for a table to open up at a nearby restaurant.  I think if I go here on a week night or a Sunday, I will like this place more.  I love wine but I don't love standing in an aisle precariously holding on to a $15 dollar glass of chintzily poured Cabernet and getting bumped into every 10 seconds by huge purses and sleazy old men who feel the need to pass by a dozen times before interrupting our conversation with, "Hi...you girls definitely don't look like virgins."  Um, yeah.  Brace yourself, ladies.

Overall selection is nice if you like California wines, though I did find the prices a little steep.  Great place to do some tasting if you can find a seat at the bar.  Not so great for a Saturday Girls Night Out.
author: Erin H.

description:
Great selection, but pricey.  Very friendly staff; they threw in a few extra tastes as I was prepping for my Sommelier exam.

Get there early on a Friday or Saturday evening; it's a narrow bar and can get crowded easily.

Good selection of "retail" wines as well, so you can do your shopping and your sipping all in one :-)
author: Nate H.

description: This place is great!!! Its just the kind of place to wind down at the end of a work day. the bartenders always have great recommendations for what you want. They seem to enjoy their jobs and are passionate about wine.
author: Anita L.

description:
This is a very strange wine bar.  It doesn't seem like any of the other wine bars I've been to in the area and I'm not just saying that because the other extreme of the scale happens to be located around the corner!  (Nectar)

This place feels like a bar that happens to serve lots of wines.  The layout is weird and they don't seem to care about the wine or chatting about their menu - they seem to be there just to pour the wine in the glass.

The only positive about this place is that they are open later than Nectar so if you're looking for wine tasting at a late hour, you can head to CWM.
author: J L.

description: Such a great place to have a good glass of wine.  The staff is friendly and they have outdoor seating which is great on a sunny day.  I have never been disappointed with this place, the only downside is that is does get crowded so off times are the best to really enjoy the venue.
author: Carly P.

description:
Casual, laid back atmostphere..  went right after work but heard it can get pretty loud and crowded as the night goes on..

pretty extensive list of wines to choose from, staff are pretty helpful in helping you choose a wine to your liking, no attitude..

also sampled the cheeseplate which I think along with chocolate truffles is the only fare on the menu..

love that the storefront opens right up to the sidewalk, makes for a comfortable place to be on a warm day.
author: Vickie Y.

description: Wine is good, but overpriced - hostess ruins the experience - sat and chatted with her friend about night before, while playing around on her phone constantly and forgets to greet the customers and do her job !
author: Rose K.

description:
The staff is always friendly. and informative. They knwo their stuff and can turn you on to a world of wines that you didnt know existed. The big bar is the only thing in the place, besides some random seating that is mostly for the tasting room. i really enjoyed hanging here, reading as I waited for a friend, and caught the comings and goings of the marina scensters. I have to say, I did my brusk opinion to some obnoxious marina-ite. who should have kept his mouth shut, but I think the wine was talking. The cheese plate has its place among those who have been drinking, maybe not a good option for date, as pointed out by the wanker running his mouth. 

Other than that, great service, wine and cute bearded men. I'll be back.
author: Sara A.

description:
Cute and fun, with a casual atmosphere. My friend and I stopped in and chatted with the bartenders one evening recently. I managed to accidentally spill wine (OK, champagne) on the woman seated next to me. Fortunately it was her birthday, and when I offered to buy her a drink while saying she didn't look a day over 21, all was forgiven. A place with clientele like that is fit to be my local hangout. 

Say hello to Tom behind the bar if you stop in.
author: Cleo B.

description:
Went here for an after-dinner tasting and really enjoyed the seating, the music, the mood, and best of all the wine. Not so sure this is the best place for what you pay, but it certainly had a decent selection of wines with an upbeat wine bar atmosphere. Corkage fees do suck. Wouldn't go out of my way recommend it to my friends, but it was a good time.

Next time we go: we'd save some dollar bills and stick to having just one good glass, and then move along to another bar to mix it up.
author: Jacob and Brianne H.

description:
Oh man, am I a total sucker for wine? Yeah. I love it, in most forms, colors, and sizes. This place had a good chance of pleasing me just because of that. 

I ended up here after a dinner up the street. The Marina isn't my hood, I've heard all the bad things people say about it, but I find it to be a crock. That being said, and having no bearing on the rest of the review, the wine was good, really good. The bartender was totally helpful, even after we'd past the point of even being able to taste any wine. 

5 stars. Most wine bars get a good grade anyway, this place nailed it.
author: Chad G.

description: Great wine bar/store. While they were busy I was able to grab a seat at the bar. Reasonably priced. They had my favorite wine. After having a glass I bought a bottle. Knowledgeable staff. Great selection. Awesome location on Chestnut. The perfect place if you want to pop in for a quick drink on a weekday night or early evening on a weekend. I know they get crowded on weekend nights. Good place to try and squeeze into for a glass of wine before going to dinner in the Marina.
author: Margot G.

description:
I use to love this wine bar in the Marina .... but the past several times I've been there the service was horrendous.  I've come to terms with the crazy prices, but I can't get over how bad the service it.  The first challenge is actually getting a menu.  You have to ask for one because a server will never acknowledge you on their own.  But then you need to beg for their attention in order to actually order a glass of wine.  (You'd think that if you ask for a menu, they would assume you are going to order soon and would keep an eye out to assist you when you are ready.  But they are oblivious of this nuance.)  The girl with the long hair is the worse, but the guy with the glasses is almost as bad.  And it's not necessarily because they are busy with other customers.  Most of the time they are busy talking to one another behind the bar and several times, they've simply been too busy playing on their phones.  

I would suggest visiting one of the several other wine bars in the neighborhood...
author: City D.

description: This place is Always packed to the Brim (and beyond) when i'm there. Tiny place, cramped and claustrophobic. BUt a good wine selection and convenient
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Indie rock music that you could hear and have a conversation (not too low, not too loud), no TVs, friendly service with no "wine bar" stuck up attitude :) Oh...and a great selection of wine!
author: Anny P.

description: They have done it again.  Guess what?  I have come back for the Muscato D'Asti...not just one bottle...but 3!  Reserved under me.  Thanx Tom!
author: Toma W.

description: Small but comfortable spot with some delicious wines to taste and buy. We sat at the bar and had a lovely time with good company.  The bar tenders could be a bit more engaging for my taste, but it was fine.  I would go back there.
author: Nilu r.

description: Nice atmosphere but some of the staff know nothing about wine. I went to purchase a bottle of Sauternes for new years eve. The lady a the bar lectures me that they don't have that one, but they have a nice Sauvignon blanc if I'd be interested. I guess they're both kindof white and both start with S..... From a business perspective I am afraid that the owner is doing the right thing by hiring a cute, young, twenty something blonde as long as she knows the difference between red and white. And THAT she did know.
author: Peter J.

description:
It's all about TOM.  

for the first few years i wasn't sure what to make of this place.  it's a meat market.  it's cool.  i like it.  but i don't like it.  "what the hell are they doing writing my order on a post-it note?"  and i thought it was totally tacky that they use glasses with water in them to mark how much they should fill the wine glasses.....and can i have more than 13 pistachios?

recently i got over all my snotty stuff and it's for ONE reason:  TOM!

Tom is like my best friend, my brother, my favorite guy in math class.  he makes me giggle.  makes me feel like i can be myself.  i'm moving soon and i want to take Tom with me.

so you better enjoy Tom and treat him right!
author: Catherine M.

description: Fun little spot on chestnut. I didn't even know that this place actually sold bottles until i walked in (yes, the sign says wine merchant but i still didn't get it) .I  always that it was just a wine bar.  It gets super packed on the weekend with the typical marina crowd.  But the Wine-tenders are super knowledgeable and the pours are decent sized.  Be warned it's a small venue, so you may need to squeeze in or wait a bit to get in.
author: Ka C.

description: Sometimes I go to the marina (Shhhhhh don't tell anyone!) just to go here. I love it. It's a great way to go for "one drink" (keep telling yourself that...like a mantra) after work. The staff are really great, and make me feel ok being in the marina, cuz I don't think they really hang out in the marina either. The playlist is really refreshing. They have a great selection of California wines (ummmm...Etude Pinot Gris. Ok? I was sold. They had me at Etude.) and then when I get kinda tipsy I get the cheese platter and don't feel bad the next day cuz I know I just mostly ate cheese and pistachios. I mean, unless I get the (God curse them) chocolate truffles. But they're really great, too. Go. And tip your bartender well.
author: Chloe N.

description:
why is it the wine i like most is always the priciest one?

the fav is 19 a pop for the castalia 06 "richioli" russian river pinot noir but if you taste it, you'll know why.

yet another marina wine bar but it's a lliiitttle bit more of a mix than the usual striped shirt and banana khaki guy and blond marina girl.  it's a bit more chill though pretty crowded at times.  if all else fails, push towards the back for some air and send the unlucky bloke or gal to get the wine orders in.

they have walls full of bottles to buy which are reasonably priced.   the more rare ones are in a glass casing. 
towards the back, is a mini sitting area for tastings.  it's not a quiet and romantic setting.  with a solid crowd and some music, it can get a wee bit deafening.

ok, i'll tack on a half star just for the pistachio bowls.  when i was left with a bunch of duds.  working hard to crack some of them drunk is not a good idea.  but the fella behind the bar happily gave me a new bowl. nice!

when they were out of the castalia, they let me try different pinot noirs until i found one that i liked.  the guys are really nice and cool here.  it's becoming my regular hang out.
author: Anh V.

description: Pretty good selection served up with the marina tax... If you don't understand the marina tax it's the we'll double the price because we know you think you can afford it. The place was packed, even on a thursday night. Even with the 10 dollar corkage I'd recommend a bottle over a couple glasses of sometimes interesting but grossly overpriced wine.
author: Alex L.

description:
My lunch for today is the review afterwards..

***

1st impression: by the looks, one heck of a ghetto ass place ... mind me, i'm comparing this with the sleek modern decor of Nectar around the corner ... what is UP with the Red & Yellow colors? Yes, the Marina has its own charm ... 

In fact, CWM def has its own charm ... Lots and lots of wine throughout the whole place ... 

Daily wine tastings ... 
Always packed, day or night ... 

Must say, they are quite generous with their pours... kinda has a wine tasting feel at one of those local wineries.

Staff = friendly and offering suggestions...

I'd say it's a great place to stop on by to simply have a quick drink since the dress code isn't like Nectar, I'd also like to say that it would be a great place to possibly pre drink before you go on your rounds of drinking ... 

I really wish they had more seatings tho.

Try to come early and score the window seats, that way, you can actually get some fresh air and people watch at the same time, like me, which is what I got to do today. 

Its DEF not nectar, but it's great to come drink and not worry about the dress code (remember, we ARE in the Marina where most people are overly made up)... 

I actually came in jeans and a baby tee, didn't really care much what the others thought and i don't think the others really cared either unlike the other places i ventured out in the marina where the other girls are checking out what the other girls are wearing and such ...  and lastly, i got to enjoy my wine...
author: Jennifer S.

description: It's the modern version of Safeway in the 70's, wherein yuppster would troll for dates.  I just wanted to buy some wine-- I'm sure if I was 20 again, I'd love it.
author: Princess P.

description: So at 5pm on a Monday night my friends were like "Do you want to go wine tasting with us tonight?'  Sure, why not - even though this place is on Chestnut, where I don't usually hang out (had to issue that little disclaimer).  It was fun - there were a lot of people there but it wasn't too crowded, and our bartender Tom was cool (I didn't know that they let guys with so many tattoos in the Marina?), and I liked his selections for our personalized flights.  I'd come back here again, especially on a Monday.
author: DD B.

description: this place strikes me as a bar disguised as a wine lounge. i prefer nectar down the street and around the corner.
author: Helen Y.

description: Great casual wine bar... just like walking into a simple cellar outfitted with wine crate shelves and generic wine-related photographs blown up for a bit of decoration.  It's a bit small and can get pretty stuffy in here despite the openness of the bar to the street.  The sommeliers are very helpful and honest, and were open to the few questions i was least ashamed to ask about the craft of vinification.
author: Marjorie B.

description: $4 tastes! Awesome to have your own wine tasting event at one location. Perfect to sample wines before dinner, which is what I did tonight...or make your own wine adventure and cab it home. I also ventured further into the back of the store to check out their enormous selection of bottles of wine.
author: Natalie S.

description: Eh, its cool.  I mean, I can't really knock any wine bar because I love wine.  But this place felt like I was drinking wine in someone's basement garage.  The music was loud and not at all what I would have expect or want to hear when leisurely sipping a nice glass of Pinot.  The two "wine guys" who served us were nice enough, but they didn't really explain the wine as much as I would have liked.  The only food they provide is a $6 cheese plate which consisted of 8-12 small square slices of one kind of cheese, a handful of pistachios, 6 olives and some bread.  I wasn't impressed.  With a few other wine bars in the neighborhood I don't think I'll make it back.
author: Ms. M. M.

description: As much as it bugs me that "Wine Star" has become so darn popular that I can rarely find a seat, its success is richly deserved. The wine list is constantly changing and extremely well-edited, and the descriptions are helpful and accurate (unlike the ridiculous descriptions at Nectar Wine Lounge). The space is unadorned but rustic, letting you know that Wine Star is about the wine, period. Extra bonus stars for the knowledgeable staff, reasonably-priced tasting events, and recent addition of a cheese plate to the menu. Minus one star for the elevated price point on bottles for retail sale -- considering the small size of the space and the income from the wine bar, I doubt overhead merits this much of a mark-up.
author: Heather F.

description: They carry Screaming Eagle!!!!  for $1300  Besides having that unattainable wine, they have a knowledgeable bartender (Angela) and a wide selection of wine!  Nice place to upgrade your wine skills and chill with friends!
author: Jason A.

description: We saw the word "wine" on the sign outside and wandered in without knowing what to expect.  I don't get it.  As a wine bar it's cramped because the retail displays obstruct the traffic around the bar so you have to negotiate your way around them.  As a wine merchant, which I take to mean "in the business of selling bottles of wine", the layout is equally strange.  The bar's high top tables are set up in front of the retail bottles so they're alternately obscured by the tables or you have to very intrusively stand in front of someone's table to look at the bottles behind it.   Seems like more of a happy hour scene that happens to only offer wine.
author: P J.

description: When I do go out in my neighborhood, this is my go-to place. It's one of the few places over here that's on the more chill side. Relatively friendly bar-tenders, and the best music in the Marina.
author: Sally M.

description: Don't believe the hype. After having high hopes, I just wasn't that impressed with this place.  The staff was ok, not all that friendly, and it seemed to have more of a pick-up scene than other wine bars.
author: shoba d.

description: Great store and good wine bar.  Helpful staff, bought a great recommended Pinot Noir here for a dinner party which was enjoyed by all, decent price at $24 a bottle.  Would come back again.
author: Audra E.

description:
decided to check out california wine merchant since we were in the general area and didn't really feel like re-visiting nectar.  it was pretty packed so it took a while for a space at the bar to clear for us to order.  decent variety in the menu, but doesn't make much difference to me since i usually stick to my favorites.

the pours are decent and the bartenders are alright.  i'm not really into the crowd though.  the music was blaring and people were screaming, as would be expected with music so loud.  a real "bar scene" but with wine breath lingering in the air as opposed to beer breath.

it was cute that they used wine crates as wall paneling but the large print photos on the walls looked amateur.  overall, it was cute for an unpretentious wine bar but i so wasn't feeling the scene.
author: spiff e.

description: Out of all the wine bars popping up and around, California Wine Merchant is one of the better ones.  So the place has a sour smell to it...it has the best wine selection of any of the wine bars around.   I know it is missing all the cool guys wearing a suit jacket, jeans and flip flops putting out the vibe, but find yourself a really nice Pinot and I am sure it will make up for it.  Normally down the street and a few blocks away, they charge an arm and a leg for some mediocre swill from Chile.  At least here you can purchase a good bottle, at a reasonable price...and if you choose not to drink it here, you can go home with it.
author: Kapeli M.

description: California Wine Merchant in the afternoon is one of the Marina's best kept secrets (oops!). Good selection of wine that seems to change daily, and good recommendations from the staff. Sometimes the crowd can be a bit ... trying at times, but who can control that? (Can someone control that? If so, please let me know. )
author: Pamela B.

description: This is a nice little wine shop/ bar. They don't have that big of a selection and I have not found the staff to be overly friendly. However, they do have a nice open store front, that takes in the afternoon sun, Very nice to have a glass and people watch. The place does get really crowded, however if you find yourself free in the late afternoon, go over and check it out.
author: Lisa A.

description: Great selection of wine! The guys behind the bar were really nice to us, and gave us recommendations of where to have dinner. We adored the cheese plate, and the wines were nice too. I would recommend this place for sure. Wish we had more time to drink there!
author: Raymond B.

description: This is one of the coziest wine bars I have found in the city.  Not only are the bartenders extremely knowledgeable and friendly, but regulars welcome you with open arms.  I've come here several times, either on weekend days or weekday evenings, and pretty much anytime it's been a good time!  Not a huge foreign selection but that's okay....the breadth of the California wines makes up for it!
author: Emma H.

description: Decent wine selection but the reason why I dislike this place or give it the rating is its pricing and how it nickel and dimes its customers.  You can buy wine by the glass or by the bottle. If you buy by the bottle, you have to pay a corkage fee. So not only do they get you for the wine, you pay for the corkage fee as well.
author: Keaton N.

description: Everytime I walk by, I expect a piece of furniture to come out the front window as in "Animal House".  I guess that could translate to one star or five stars depending on your preference.
author: Ron O.

description: This is a hit or miss place for me... well.. mostly miss.  Did I mention miss?  Anyway.. I enjoy myself here because of the company and not because of the wine or the service.  If you need a glass filled with water to regulate your wine portions... you lose another star from this guy...   This place needs to get a touch of class!
author: Tom C.

description: This was the third of four wine bars of the night, and easily the best.  We went on a Tuesday night and it was pretty packed.  The service was attentive, the bartenders were very nice and quick to get drinks/food.  It has a non-pretentious look although its in the Marina, its much more casual/social than Nectar Wine Lounge which is down the street.  The cheese plate was pretty cheap / good, I highly recommend this place.
author: Marc M.

description: Last weekend we had a syrah for under 50 bucks that was amazing. This place kicks ass, where else can you hang, drink wine at retail prices, and the few times ive been there ive found people to be very friendly.  Def better during the week than on wknd.
author: Honest A.

description: CWM moved over a few blocks and converted to a store/bar hybrid which works well. The bar can get crowded on weekends and nice days. Prime seating is up front when the windows are open overlooking Chestnut. Don't expect anything from France or Australia, this is strictly Californian.
author: Patrick B.

description: Great playlist. Mellow ambiance, friendly and knowledgeable owners recommending the perfect wines. Cozy wine barrel table in the back, low key and warm, reasonably priced cheese platter. All very pleasing and non-Marina-like.
author: Purnima M.

description: Great place to kick back and enjoy a good glass of wine.
author: Ryan P.

description:
SLOW, jesus people.

Oh, what's that? I just bought a bottle of wine from you and I have to pay a $20 corkage fee??!! WTF!! I bought it FROM YOU. It is already MARKED UP. It's not like I brought a bottle in myself. Idiots.

Plus there is nowhere to sit. The owner himself takes up a chair, not even thinking to offer it to the young lady and her friends who just got ripped off.

Hate this place. Went on over to Nectar. I bought a bottle and they didn't charge me to open it.
author: k h.

description: I am not sure if CWM is new but i have never noticed it before i visited there last night for drinks.  some friends of mine that live near there said that its always busy so they were curious about trying it.  and it was busy - lots of people at the bar and all the tables.  service was pretty good though - we only had to wait a little at the bar.  i dont know too much about wine, but the winelist looked pretty broad and the red wine i had was delicious.  not sure i would go back that much since the marina really isnt my scene, but if i was looking for a wine bar down there, this was a good spot.
author: Carolyn B.

description: A pocket of Benevolence in the Dark Zone. Man, I have to REALLY like a place in the Marina to be willing to frequent it.  This place, which has a sign calling it Wine Star, is good enough to make me want to brave all the Carolyn Bessette Kennedyesque double-wide-stroller-pushing Marina chicks and their feckless menfolk.  Even at it's busiest, the two staff on hand were friendly, efficient, and really knowledgeable. Great interior atmosphere, the perfect place to wind up. Even the patrons were friendly which makes me think maybe they were all from other zones. Loved everything I drank or sipped.  Happy Birthday to Todd!
author: Kevin S.

description: Ah, wine bars...eternally pleasant, yet rarely memorable.  But if nothing else, CWM stands out as by far the most crowded wine bar I've ever been to (thank you, Marina!).  Still, it managed to stay far more cordial than boisterous, and it was plenty easy to hear yourself give your friends dubious relationship advice (it being the low-inhibition end of the evening, after all).  Somebody in our group stuck a delicious glass of Syrah into my hand, but I have no idea what it cost (safe to say it's a bit pricey here, though).  Mega props for having Clif Bar-brand wine (alcohol and outdoor adventure sports, together at last!).
author: Wes M.

description: I must agree with Kevin here ... who would have thought this place would be so cool and yet hold the address of "Chestnut Street"? Once a small, dark, hole-in-the-wall store on Pierce Street, the California Wine Merchant took their eviction news rather well. Since the move, their business has tripled. And their do-it-yourself wine bar idea has made them the kings of the pour. Make sure to use this place as a wine store too ... the staff is not shy and will help you find the best of the cheap, or the best of the not-so-cheap. I am impressed at how these guys didn't sell out, but stepped it up and braved a new start in a trendy hood.
author: Amanda C.

description: If you enjoy drinking your wine with the bros, then definitely come here. Otherwise, skip on over to Nectar.  Or go early, grab the window table, and channel your inner Miles over a glass of Pinot.
author: Chris B.

description:
i've walked by this place a bunch of times, but never really felt compelled to go on. i finally had a chance when my friend happened to be there, so my and my other girlfriend stopped by after dinner. it was really crowded but we were able to grab a couple of seats at the bar. the bartenders seemed to busy to really talk wine and although there were descriptions, i would've liked to have asked them to elaborate a bit more. 

we each got a 'taste' of different wines and although they were quite generous, i ended up liking my friends more and she liked mine, so we swtiched. i didn't really like hers that much, i just thought it was better than mine. 

i doubt i'll go back, it's too much like a bar scene, but they only serve wine. when i go to a wine bar i'm usually looking for a more chill enivornment, but i felt like it was too crowded and too much of a scene. maybe a more mellow night, but friday night was just too crowded, for a wine bar at least.
author: Angela W.

description: Fun (and unpretentious) place to try some new wines.  The wine selection, as one would imagine at a wine tasting shop, is HUGE & the staff is knowledgeable and incredibly helpful in assisting you in your selection.  The tables by the front are great to drink your wine and watch people pass by on Chestnut.
author: Katie P.

description:
While I enjoy wine, love to buy it, I really no jack squat about it.

Going to a place like the California Wine Merchant is great because you have the chance to talk to someone who actually knows a thing or two about wine. And of course sample some of these. Problem is this place can be very crowded sometimes. Best to go on an off night.

Place has a comfortable setting, and I like sitting amongst all the wine bottles and barrels. How is someone not stealing wine from this place!?!?! I want to call them bartenders but might be to lowly. So the "wine servers/pour-ers" are very friendly and knolwedgable, as they should be. 

Place is a great way to spend an evening on Chesnut St. but that does not happen to often. As wine bars is up ther with visiting the dentist for me.
author: David B.

description: I went in recently with a friend for one post-dinner glass of wine and woke up the next day with perhaps my worst wine-induced hangover EVER.  I blame that on the two of us being the only two-woman party under 35 that night.  Neither of us is particlularly blonde or bitchy, which I thought were the key ingredients to getting free pours in the Marina.  The guys behind the bar were very knowledgeable and friendly (Brant and Greg, I think - but don't quote me), so I'm confused by other reviewers' comments about terrible service.  I'd go back, but I'd stick to my one glass plan next time...
author: katie m.

description: We went in here for a wine tasting. It was fun, a fun atmosphere. But, a little crowded. CWM is trying to be a wine store and a bar, and if you're a wine lover, it's heaven.  The tasting fee was pricey, even by Napa standards.
author: Julian H.

description: Gotta go with 3 stars on this ... the window + afternoon sun is a winning combo. BUT the deafening music (really? you thought I wanted to listen to this and in turn scream to my friends?) and having to crawl through the crowd to get a glass of wine knocks my vote down to 3 stars.
author: Heather C.

description: I love this wine bar especially since it's very out of the ordinary for the "under-30-I'm-rich-and-living-off-my-parents-money-good-looking-and-I-think-I'm-cool-and-talk-real fast-and-on-my-cell-phone-real-loud" Marina crowd.  If it's not that crowded you can get great service but when it's real crowded it's not so great (hence the 4 vs. 5 stars).  I love that atmosphere here and they serve up some pretty nice wines.  They are pretty knowledgeable also.  They let you taste a little if you're interested.
author: Mitch A.

description: A lot of great wine at really reasonable prices. I can't say the patrons are people I would want to sit and strike up conversation with, but if you go here in good company to simply enjoy good wine, you will not be disappointed. I always go out on a bit of a limb when I decide what to enjoy here and have really never regretted a decision I've made. Maybe they just stock that many great wines, or maybe I should be a sommelier in my next life.
author: Alicia J.

description: $15 tastings on Monday nights and they have some good California wineries that participate.  The staff is quite knowledgeable.  If you want to buy a bottle of their wine and drink it there, they charge you ten bucks on top of the cost of the bottle which is a bit chintzy.  Definitely a cougar hangout, and a much less sterile atmosphere than Nectar around the corner...one of the better wine bars in town.
author: Geoff K.

description: If it's not too packed this is the perfect place to grab a glass of wine with friends. Not pretentious, just good wine. Unfortunately, it's usually a madhouse!
author: Sarah R.

description: This place is great for me if its no too crowded. If its standing room only than I walk right by. The staff's knowledge of wine is a hit or miss. I really do not trust the wine by the glass list. If you have some time,  just buy a bottle you know and drink it on the premise. I think its about $15 corkage.
author: Chris N.

description: They do have a good selection of wine... but come one they need glasses on the bar filled with water to know how much wine to pour in a glass! WTF?!?  I'm paying $15 for a glass of zin (which yes was good) but at the same time you're going to measure it.  My friends also told me that if you buy a bottle there they charge you a corkage.  Unreal.  too many other great wine bars in this city who don't have to measure.  Times are tough - I want to drink a lot of wine...
author: Jodi B.

description: Fabulous. My favorite place for Sunday afternoons.
author: Jennifer B.

description: This is the second time I have been here.  The wine list is at least decently long but overall, the wines are definitely a bit pricey.  We were there late at night and the place was full.  My friends and I had a great time not only chatting with each other, but the scene and crowd made the evening more amusing.  Didn't get a chance to talk to the bartender about suggestions, but oh well.  I would probably go back here not really to taste wine (at least not at midnight) but rather for the atmosphere and the fact that you could still hear your friends and hold conversations without having to scream over the noise and music like you'd have in other places.
author: A L.

description: I've been to the Wine Merchant on Warm Nights when they have had the front windows open and it has had a really fun summer vibe and warm nights when they've been closed and it's been really cozy.  It is a perfect place to bring a group of friends and enjoy a great glass of wine.  The Etude Pinot Noire...Fantastic!
author: Diane R.

description: During the week this place is fantastic.  Not too crowded, large pours, dark cozy atmosphere, and the nice Chestnut street life vibe without much, if any, of the overdone marina feel.  From passing by it looks very busy on weekend nights, which must make for a totally different experience.
author: J P.

description: I LOVE this place!  Excellent wine and friendly service...for those who care deeply about their grapes.  YUM!
author: Sarah D.

description: Friendly and fantastic service!  The atmosphere is very chill...where walking in with your cap and favorite tee won't make you feel out of place.  Pop in some Jack Johnson on their playlist and I'm enjoying wine the way it should be, in good company and overall good times.
author: Jeff A.

description: The people here look like they're enjoying themselves.  Good selection but wines are way overpriced.
author: Mia G.

description: Good place, with a nice wine list. But this place gets seriously PACKED since it's pretty small and there are not that many tables. Good luck finding a seat and being able to have a conversation. Other than that, I really do like the place (or maybe that's just the wine talking)..
author: Rosie S.

description: I love this spot. Yes, it's small, but they always find room for you. There are so many different kinds of wine, from the super cheap (red guitar) to the fabulous and expensive (dumol, copain, etc.). They have wonderful wine tastings and the best staff - I love Tom and Kelly, they are fun, nice and helpful! Just a great place to hang out on a week night...weekends get way too packed!
author: Shelley M.

description: Pretty decent wine selection.  This place is quite small though and does get crowded with folks that like to linger around for a bit.  Great place to catch up with your girlfriends and not feel like you're going to get hit on every few seconds.  Yellow post-it notes and pens hover in front of every 2-3 seats around the bar.  We found out its purpose later on that night.
author: Jean A.

description: I always called this place Wine Star. Huh. Anyway, it's a great place to sit on a sunny day and have a glass of wine.
author: Carson H.

description: Great marina place for a glass of wine..or a bottle..or two! Check out the wine tastings too. Small but cozy.
author: Not M.

description: Such a surprising place considering the dive that was at this location before. Father and son have turned this place into the perfect place to enjoy non pretentious wine with friends.  Good to see that their intial success is still going strong.
author: Frederic B.

description: Interesting wine list and good people watching. It's fun to stop in on a sunny afternoon, grab a glass and relax.
author: Jason B.

description: Like this place a lot. Service is always great. The one thing that I wish there was more of are seats and room. It would be great if they could somehow expand as to avoid the stare down when you're sitting and the race competition to get the seats when someone gets up and leaves...Wine selection is fab and service is prompt and polite.
author: michaela w.

description:
Whenever I'm in search of a wine bar, I always remember passing by this place and thinking how cute it is, but it's always so busy and crowded that I'm not tempted to go in. However, a few days ago I got to leave work early and decided to book it over to Chestnut and try my luck. And as luck would have it, in my first round of looking for parking I found a spot right in front of the bar- which really is a sign to go in!

Unfortunately there were no open seats at the bar, so my friend and I opted to sit at the makeshift table made out of a barrel near the back of the bar. The bar's set up was a little awkward b/c the bar itself could only accommodate about 10 people and there were no additional sittings except for two seats in the back. And when I drink wine I like to be sitting and lounging.

As for the wine- it was good. I thought they had a good selection for a decent price and I was happy with my selection. If you're looking to sit and relax drinking your wine I would come here in the late afternoon, but if you don't mind standing and wanting to chat with strangers you'd most likely enjoy their evening atmosphere better.
author: Samantha F.

description: So I had a two-hour non-alcoholic dinner with my mom at Isa in which we talked about my life, my career, my plans for the future, basically all that shit that makes you want to stab yourself with a butter knife.  After that torture had ended, I was congratulating myself for not stabbing myself with said knife when that nagging Irish/Russian background a.k.a. incipient alcoholism started to kick in on the walk back to my car.  Enter this "winestar."  $10 glass of wine?  Whatever dude, just get me some liquor.  I paid $25 for two parsimonious pours but they were totally delicious.  At my house we drink Two Buck Chuck.  And the drive up and down Divisadero back to the slums is so much more fun after a couple drinks.
author: S P.

description: They have an extensive selection of nice wine.  The atmosphere is a little cramped and the bar tendeders are a little cranky but all in all it's a nice place to grab a glass of wine in the evenings.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: I like going here simply because it is a great place to catch a glass or bottle before or after your evening. Yes they do not serve food and yes it gets crowded on the weekends but you are missing the point of the place if are thinking of a lounge or all night bar.
author: Samer A.

description: I love this bar.  It is as low key or wild as you make it.  They have really well informed but down to earth staff to help you find the perfect choice to fit your mood.
author: Jessica V.

description: I love this place, it feels like you are in a tasting room in napa to me. It even smells like you are on the inside of a wine barrel. My only complaint is that there are a lot of over aged wasted men. Go with friends and buy bottles.
author: Lisa M.

description: Pretty cool place. I went on a Monday for a specific winery's tasting event. They have a different winery every week supposedly. $20 for 8 (I think?) tastings. Everyone is really chill. The owner hangs out with the customers and is really nice.
author: David K.

description: I used to come here more when it first opened, but now it is always so packed to the gills I can't stand it.  Still, when you can find a seat it is a nice treat.  Like being at an actual winery.  Good little cheese plate if you need a nibble.
author: e w.

description:
This friendly neighborhood bar definitely has more of the "Cheers" vibe than other pretentious bars the area offers. 
Novice when it comes to wine? 
The bartenders are so versed in California vino they're able (and happy) to match a wine with your palette (and budget).
Already an oenophile?
The owner has been in the industry for years and has the connections to prove it. The bar is full of boutique names hard to find anywhere else -- let alone by the glass.
Taken back by the corkage fee?
"Kh" seemed a little disturbed by the corkage fee the bar tacks on to bottles purchased from the walls...however the merchant is just that -- a merchant. Although the bar is almost always packed, a big part of the business is selling wine to people who take it home or to a dinner party (they'll even wrap the bottle for a last minute gift). The wine on the walls is only slightly marked up for this reason (the liquor store down the street sells some of the same bottles for double the price). If "Kh" doesn't want to drink the wine off the four page menu and prefers a bottle off the wall she's gonna have to pay a little more for it.
My advice?
Stop complaining and go drink your $10 martini and $5 beer down the street. If you want a reasonably priced glass of wine surrounded by good company, where everyone knows your name, head to the California Wine Merchant.
author: Somer F.

description: How can you go wrong?  Casual friendly atmosphere and a great selection of Pinot Noirs!
author: angela n.

description: This is the perfect place for sinlges in their late 40's/50's... Total pick up scene, small, packed, rude service.  The wines aren't bad, California only.  I do like the fact they have a focus, but I wouldn't go back.  Too much of an older, rich, prissy pick up scene.
author: john s.

description: Here is the story with this place. They have an excellent selection of West Coast wines. Including some hard to find Sonoma Coast Pinots, Some nice OR Pinots and some very pricey Napa Cabs. BUT in general this place is a complete rip off. I bought a couple of expensive bottles one night and the kid working there charged me for corkage. I protested but it didn't fly so I paid and decided not to return. Also the staff is a bit snooty. Too bad because the location and the wine selection is top notch.
author: kyle m.

description: friendly neighborhood wine joint.  kickback and perfect for people watching. i was on a wine kick this weekend (started off with press club extravaganza...ended here)
author: Angela N.

description: a biker dive become a wine dive.  the fact that the selection of wines here is virtually devoid of offerings from more than a 200 mile radius of here keeps this from rising above the rabble...well, that and the youngish barkeep that wasn't aware of what a corked wine might be.  still, even if the selection is limited and the available food is just a step above the communal pretzel bowl, the vibe is moderately grooving as the wine-steeped marina denizens stumble in and out, miraculously, without knocking over or stealing any of the bottles by the entrance conveniently located within the swinging arc of an elbow. open late however, so available for that last ditch effort to bust a move over a nominally sophisticated bev.
author: Kosuke I.

description: A small group of us went in last night... not even that busy, but had to wave down the bartender to get service, then, when we asked to taste (a small sip) one of the expensive wines, were told that "we don't do that - you can buy a taste"........ COME ON!  It's a WINE BAR & they are trying to sell WINE.... it's expensive by the glass, we've seen them have to pour next to a glass with water so they don't accidentally give you a drop more then the prescribed amount.    A visit to nearby restaurants or wine bars will get you a knowledgable  server, the ability to sip something you're thinking of trying & nicer atmosphere.
author: Susan R.

description: i don't get the criticism.  i've now trained the bartender to play thin lizzy every time i visit.  is that what you bed-wetters don't like?  fuck it - as long as i'm having fun.  it's all about me.
author: schnarf-a-larf a.

description: Great service and affordable, tasty wines!  The bartenders have not led me wrong when recommending something.
author: Joyful Jenny H.

description: Perfect wine bar. Great place to hang with friends, meet new ones and of course, drink great wines. Not pretentious at all!
author: Rachel B.

description: It's too bad my first Yelp! review is a negative...but the bitter taste (was it the wine or the service?) has lingered.  Just because I'm not over 35, seeking the company of a graying, tapered pant and boat shoe wearing cougar-lover, I still expected to receive a notion of service and a few actual suggestions to replace my choices of the wines they had supposedly run out of.  Read: the less expensive ones are always, surprise surprise, "gone".  Instead, however, I was left to try not to eavesdrop on everyone I was standing in.  In the middle of my order, which had to be yelled over a couple sitting at the bar, was interrupted by a clone of the bar tender I mentioned earlier.  They shook hands (in between the couple at the bar), laughed about how the bartender's ex-wife was sitting at one end of the bar, while he was waiting on his new blond wine-interest of the moment.  He then proceeded to remember I was there took my order and ignored myself and two friends the rest of the night.  All that for a $14 glass.  I should have purchased a bottle of BV from Safeway.
author: Crystal K.

description: I really like this place!  The servers are friendly...and it's casual, so attracts both girls and guys. I like to stop here for a glass of wine while out shopping with the girls or before heading to dinner.  Also, the tastings are a good size portion.
author: Kelly M.

description: Not sure who the hell the bartenders here think they are but they seem to have a sense of entitlement about tips.  The place has a good selection off wines.  You can buy a bottle to take home (just like a wine shop), or you can pick a bottle, they will open it for you and you get to drink it there for an additional 15% corkage fee.  We were a fairly large group and were in the back for a friends birthday.  We bought 3 or 4 bottles they opened them for us, gave us glasses and that was it.  We didn't ask their advice, and they didn't serve us or even come by to chat.  At the end we were told off for not tipping on our large tab.  And it was done in a very snide, impolite way.  (sweetie, I don't care if you are pretty, you need to lern that tips are EARNED)  We all assumed that the corkage fee covered the service of opening the wine and using their glasses.  If we had been at the bar and gotten advice, glasses poured  I might have understood their gripe.  But we were in the back on our own.  In any case, it's just another reason to hate the Marina...
author: Priscilla C.

description: I like the fact that they are open an hour later than nectar but one person's cozy is another (i.e. this person's) "unable to transition from a store to an actual wine bar"... it still seems to be finding it's vibe and the crowd in there has been very hit or miss for me...
author: Anjali K.

description:
had a few glasses on a sunday night. sat by the table by the window and watched people go by. the staff is nice. they have a good selection that is not overpriced and if you get a taste, you get half a glass for half the price. 
they dont really want you to buy a bottle though because its a $15 corkage if you do.
author: Yelper S.

description: I'm not really into the Marina scene, but I keep coming back, so maybe I secretly do like the Marina scene, and after a pretty good meal at Isa we hopped over to Bin 38 which was OK, but typical Marina boring. We then went over the California Wine Merchant per usual, not sure why I really even try new places in the Marina because I inevitably always   end up here. It was packed on a Wednesday night, but not your typical douche bags, this place has cool, fun clientele, it's a bit more of hard drinking wine bar if that makes sense, so the crowd is all ages and fairly energized. I've met some really cool people here, which defeats my waffling Marina hatred, and this place is really just a good ol' fashioned loud bar, who happens to carry some of the best wines ever by the glass. That's the bottom line here, the wines are the best California has to offer, and the bartenders per usual made perfect recommendations that were spot on and totally unique. I had an O'Connor Pinot, which I'd never heard of which was great, a Lucia Pinot, which I've never seen by the glass anywhere else, it was divine, finally at the playful advocation by the cute girls next to me had a T-Vine Grenache, which was extraordinary, and I think only they carry the wine. So the bar is super loud, super cramped, and super expensive, you can't get these wines anywhere else, and I don't think they are trying to be a quiet wine bar, they're open until 1:30 in the morning, the bartenders are more like Mission hipsters, the crowd was the whole Marina-un-Marina thing, good loud music, though the prices are definitely Marina, you're getting what you pay for.  We stayed until 1:15 and my head was pounding the next morning at work, but without a doubt the best wine bar in the Marina area, and second only to District in the city.Only complaints are that it takes forever to get a barstool and there are certainly some date-rapey girl trollers in this place. Even the uber-rich need bars to black out in, and this is that place!!
author: Steve l.

description: This was the first bar that I went to when I moved to San Francisco two years ago and it's where I take all out of town visitors.  The wine list is excellent (try a T-Vine red, there's one on the menu every other time I visit).  It can certainly be expensive but if you plan to stay for a while and aren't just there to taste, buy a bottle and it will save you a ton.  The bartenders are generally very knowledgeable and are super nice, especially Nate.  I wish they had more than one token international selection but this place has helped me learn a lot about my taste in California wine.  On Monday nights, someone from a vineyard will visit from 6pm to 9pm and you can taste everything they brought for $15.
author: K S.

description: Since there are hundreds of wineries that produce fantastic wine within an hour's drive of this place, I expected a diverse wine list with lots of labels I'd never heard of.  That expectation was disappointed.  Their selection of local wines was limited and didn't include much of anything you can't buy at a wine shop in Chicago. The place is pretty small, but the people behind the bar were nice.
author: PG M.

description: This place has always been very casual and fun.  You can take a bottle from their shelves and pay a small corkage and drink with friends.  Stand in the back for more room or sit in the front for the open-air feeling.  The bartenders are all pretty nice.  Great place to hang.
author: Brian L.

description: Good wines selections...especially when you're looking for a hard to find bottle. And, you always run into someone you know in the Marina crowd; however, the oftentimes rude service is not eclipsed by the positives on most nights.
author: Heather S.

description: This is my favorite wine bar in the city.  The buyers seem to have a very similar taste to my wife and I.  Lots of big, bold, rich flavors.  The place gets really, really packed, but its well worth it for the great wine.  I would say this place is the best in comparison to the others I've been into the city like SNOB, Baccus, and Cav
author: William S.
